I would thoroughly recommend this for a tranquil family day out close to the centre of London, but without all the fuss and cafuffle.
Calm in the City. One of many of London's beautiful parks. A perfect spot for a half hour rest from sight seeing. Lots of wildfowl.

Bird's Paradise. There are many, maybe too many, parks in London but this one is famous for bird-watching (the real species).....there are real swans in the lake. There may be even better parks but this one is central. Make special trip only if you want to see Swan Lake without paying for the Royal Opera House admission.
Beautiful gardens next to Buckingham Palace. Beautiful gardens and water bodies. Wonderful place to walk around and take pictures if you are looking to kill some time.

As much green as to be had. It was overcast and few were out in the cold, but some fresh air and seeing squirrels run freely around the park gave us some hope. It was good to see normal people going about their leisure in tranquil surroundings.
Beautiful Place. Beautiful open space with lakes and animals, next to the Buckingham palace, with beautiful yards, and a walking distance from the big bang and westminster abbey.

A pleasant meander. This was a nice walk back through the park with my grandchildren after having walked up the Mall to Buckingham Palace. There were plenty of pathways and things to look at. Many variety of water birds on the water, with squirrels on the grass and in the trees. Snack shacks to get a drink, but beware the one we stopped at had rats running about behind and underneath it. Not many available toilets in the park, or not that we found. This was a pleasant walk even though it was 1st February and cold, I have been there in Summer and it is a very nice place to while away a couple of hours.

Beautiful park right in the heart of London. Walk in this park frequently - it is beautiful, lovely lakes , trees & flowers lots of ducks & swans & other birds - right next to Buckingham Palace lovely place to walk anytime of the year & just near lots of tube stations

Very lovely walking tour -- amazing bird life. I was totally surprised by the park. I didn't know exactly where i was going and found myself in St. James Park by accident. Loved the birdlife and the little bridge over the water. Good views for photos with birds, water, and landmarks all in focus. Nice access to Shoryu Ramen shop on Regent Street if you are hungry after your walk!

Nice walk around.. Nice walk around, there's a few places to get something to eat or drink. Nice walk through the park up to Buckingham Palace.
Nice lake, lots of birds/squirrels, plenty of places to sit down.

Beautiful park. I absolutely adore this park. Always a favourite of mine in the summer. There's a large pond full of wildlife. They have a children's play park and a nice cafe which does a variety of food and drink. Toilets are readily available and there is often art and exhibitions going on. Definitely worth a visit!

Watery oasis in Central London. St James's Park provides a wonderful oasis for wildlife in the heart of London. Over the centuries the lake in the middle has taken many forms. Originally one of London's lost rivers, the Tyburn flowed through here. James I was the first person to start landscaping the park with ornamental pools and a menagerie of exotic animals and birds. He had an aviary running along what is now Birdcage walk. Charles II replaced the pools with a long straight canal, which in turn was returned back to a more natural lake by George IV. Today the park is still populated by many ducks, swans and other waterfowl. The most famous residents are the pelicans. The views from the bridge in the middle are quite unique, with Buckingham Palace reflected in the lake one side and a couple of fountains up the opposite end. There is a very handy and clean café and toilet block at the Marlborough entrance to the park on the Mall.

Beautiful park, lots of birds!. There were Pelicans, swans, geese, ducks and LOTS of squirrel!! Be aware that the squirrel are VERY used to people and one even started climbing up my husbands leg! But I've had a lovely stroll though the park, even though it was winter, it was still very nicely maintained, and the pond had lots of different fowl swimming around.
Squirrels galore - kids loved it. Being winter, the park isn't in its full glory but still beautiful to walk through. The squirrels were out in force and the kids loved watching them.

A green oasis in London. A great place to just wander and get lost in thought. Even in December it had things to see - go find out for yourself. And just in case, there is a restaurant and tea room so you will not risk starvation.
pleasant small park in the center of London. nice to cross if you have to walk between Victoria/Buckingham and Trafalgar/Big Ben, also if you are not a tourist
Fantastic. Full of activities and people. Nice place to chill out or know new people. I have to put at least 50 characters

Pleasant stroll. There are many beautiful birds at the park. I especially loved the squirrels - two of them climbed on me in search of food, which I didn't have. If you are with children, you should probably be careful, they are fast and hungry!

Great little park. Of the three parks around the Palace, this has the most variety and density of activity and events. Not secret but sometimes forgotten in the shadow of the larger Green and Hyde Parks.
Love this park. Very nice place to feel relax. Lots of greens and animals.

Perfect for a picnic. As soon as the sun comes up, this is where I like to go. It's in a stunning location, and you can always find a quiet place to sit. Yet if you want to have a kick about, you can do that too. It's a perfect place to have a picnic and I highly recommend it. For such a central park, it's nice and quiet.

Winter Wonderland. Winter wonderland was a great experience for all ages. Lots of rides, ice rink, ice museum, christmas marked and exciting rides for younger children/teenages and adults. Plenty of places to eat and drink

Magic oasis in Westminster. beautifully laid out, wonderful arching trees, a lake that holds the entire park together, St James's Park is a very special place - Horseguards parade at the easterly end and Buck House in the West. Brilliant British ability to maximise the impact of this small space, covered by history. Lovely all the time of the year - especially Spring and Summer. grab a sandwich or a bottle of wine and sit and watch life walk by. It reaches many of the senses.
Infrastructure getting old. Enjoyed the green, the park is lively and yet offers privacy. The somewhat outdated infrastructure however discounted my overall experience.

Winter or summer, always nice!. always calming and relaxing to take a walk on the park even if there is 2 celsius degrees! (Like it was)!!Lakes, ducks, trees, and almost any noise from the outside busy life of London!
Wonderful open space. Freedom to roam. Squirrels were a pest if you have any food, but guess they are only trying to feed themselves.
lovely in winter. Visit this park for an urban oasis in winter. Black swans and lovely trees and ponds. Very calm and peaceful and few people! Wonderful walk to and from Buckingham and downtown.

BEAUTIFUL!!!. What variety and colors at artfully displayed along the banks of the ponds with glimpses of various landmarks like Buckingham Palace, the Royal Parade Grounds, and London Eye to name a few in the carefully orchestrated vistas complete with fountains and a menagerie of waterfowl.I'm an early-risers, so pretty much had the park to myself before the crowds arrived
Beautiful park. Be aware that the squirrels are very tame and friendly. Our children were able to coax them to climb up their legs without even a treat to offer them.
Lovely park. Lovely Park between Buckingham Palace and House of Parliament. Beautiful lake with swans and ducks make it a place for a beautiful walk.
A nice walk through the Park. It was the nice walk through the Park and we really enjoyed it. The colors of the trees, the animals, the atmosphere, everything was great!
Do the "Walks" walk!. Excellent guided 2 hour walk around the area with Walks company.Very imformative,excellent value for money
Lovely park. Great for a short walk and loads of wildlife to look at. Squirrels everywhere that are so tame and will eat from your hand. Always end up here each time we're in London.
Lovely park!!. Quite and nice little park inside the heart of the city. Loved the squirrels who 'beg' for some food or nuts...
sunshine in the park. Well cared for and as someone who comes from the country was pleasantly surprised by different varieties of birds and ducks

The best London park I visited. It's full of lots of various birds,cute squirrels, nice lake with a little bridge. It's not a huge park, but compact one, and although it is centrally located it can be peaceful at times with not too many people in it. It doesn't have the huge grassy spaces of Hyde Park and Green Park and it's so nice for walking and sitting on a bench and just relaxing and enjoying the fauna and various trees and bushes :) My fave one in London so far.

Beautiful place for a stroll. What a beautiful park in an optimum London location. Walking through it it's hard to believe that you're in the centre of a city. It was chilly when I walked through here so a brisk pace was needed, but in the summer it's a great place to stroll, sit and have a takeaway lunch.

Nice Park. Walked through on the way to watch the changing of the guard and enjoyed handing peanuts to the squirrels and watching all of the different birds that inhabit the area. Of course it is winter so I am sure it is much nicer in the summer when everything is lush and green.

Cute animal life. Great place to visit. Surrounded by many tourist attractions. The park is full of lovely cute squirrels, ducks, swans and even saw a happy fox. The locals even commented that they had not seen that before. The kids took a lot of photos of the squirrels running up and down the trees and across the grass.

Squirrels. I love parks, and this one is packed with animals running around. The squirrels are so used to people feeding them that you just need to crouch reach out and they'll come to you. Careful they bite.
Loved it!

Nice stroll to the Palace. Great wild life - numerous squirrels that ate food from your hand. We walked quite easily from the Horse Guards Museum across the parade ground, through the park to Buckingham Palace then along The Mall to Nelson's Column and back to the river taxi at Westminster Pier.
Summer holiday. Every visit to this place seems like a holiday. An oasis of charm amid the cacophony of the capital.
cheeky chap. We sat in the park to have our sandwich and watch the world go by.As we did a cheeky squirrel jumped on my knee for a bite to eat. We also saw parrots in the trees! !

A wonderful park next to the Palace. This park was very clean and fun. There's loads of swans, geese and other birds roaming around as well as squirrels that climb up you if you let them. It's next to Pall Mall and Buckingham Palace. It's walking distance to a tube station. A great place to wind down with kids if you're visiting London!

Always lovely. Been St James Park many times on my trips to London, always clean, and lovely. No complaints, apart from tourists feeding the pigeons etc. never any little and brilliant views on the bridge
Clean and impressive. A nice place to go if you want to clear the lungs after a night out. It is central to most of the major sights in London and it is good to see the dogs roaming free.

Beautiful! . As all parks in London, St. James Park is beautiful, but hosting no other than the Buckingham palace.
There are squirrels, crows, and lots of birds who love to be fed !
A must see when in London

what a beauty. We took a stroll round this park before visiting Buckingham Palace as they are so close. so much greenery and wildlife.. we didn't get round the park as much as we wanted as the squirrels had our attention too long. They are hilarious.
Make sure you go armed with Monkey Nuts and you sure will have fun!

Grab a sandwich, find a bench and soak it in. A park right next to Buckingham Palace, smack in the centre of London but feeling miles away, in a quaint British village somewhere.It truly is a special treat. Green grass, hilarious squirrels, so many benches to get comfortable on while soaking up the views of the Eye and the tourists that walk by.We wandered this park for around 45 minutes and really appreciated the sense of calm it brought to us.

Great Park and lovely ambiance on a beautiful day. Loved the park, so typically British, water, birds, squirrels, wildlife in abundance. Nice food stalls also. Lovely walk from Trafalgar Square to Buck Palace.

Nice recreation area. The park is close to the palace, so you can do at least both in one day. You can watch pelicans, squirrels and other animals while sipping a tee or having a small bite from one of the small shops inside the park.

Not too big. Lots of sites nearby. One of the must do london landmarks. A good walk around looking at the birds and squirrels is fun, there are a few pieces of play equipment for kids. Buckingham palace and horse guards is nearby, plus the barracks has some band practice and marching to enjoy in the morning. Nice place for a picnic, if you are lucky you'll see a big pelican, and if you are luckier still you may see one eat a duck or pigeon.

A walk in the park. Over the Christmas holiday we stayed on The Strand and took the opportunity on several occasions to stroll through and around St. James's Park.It is a wonderful space and, during the holiday, was a great place to take some gentle walking exercise, stop off at various points to admire the surroundings, and enjoy some respite from the traffic and hectic activities of the nearby Trafalgar Square and Charing Cross areas.The walk from Admiralty Arch, taking a detour by Horse Giards Parade and up through to Buckingham Palace is to be recommended.
Nice and central.... park almost right inbetween Trafalgar Square and Buckingham Palace. A very calm and smaller park in the big city. Great place to catch your breath for a minute or so.

Never Knew London Had So Much Greenery. This small but magnificent park right next to Buckingham Palace is always filled with strollers who come to watch the swans and the other water fowl who so naturally flock to the park's ponds. A must see when in London.

Central Park. St James's Park is the green space between Buckingham Palace and Horseguards Road. It occupies absolutely prime location in the heart of London. St James is quite a small park but does pack in a lot of fearless wildlife.The biggest attraction to St James is its wildlife. The squirrels are notoriously bold. Ducks and geese are always on the lookout for food. The pelicans though are probably the stars of the show.The park has a stream at its centre, a nice waterway to add backdrop especially with willow trees. A bridge over the stream is impressive because when crossing it there is a direct view to Buckingham Palace as well as towards Horseguards Parade - potentially romantic after dark.There are a few trees in St James but it is mainly open grass. The grass is well maintained through all seasons. The pathways are wide which comes in handy as large tourist groups can block routes quite easily. St James is a nice park but not especially exciting or interesting. There are a couple of attractive angles but its best feature is definitely the location rather than the park itself.

Simply beautiful. Beautiful, quiet park in close proximity from Buckingham Palace and you may visit on the same day, after the changing of the guards. It is almost unbelievable that such a serene place lies in the middle of bustling London. You can see squirrels, ducks, swans and many other.

Loved it. Really enjoyed the walk through the park, kids enjoyed the nosey squirrels that kept coming up to you looking for food, recommend taking a bad of nuts! Plenty of bird life about and places to get hot drinks! Really worth a visit for a more quiet place in London.

A beautiful park, just next to the palace.. Only a couple of minutes walk from Buckingham Palace, this is an extremely elegant small park.The park features a lovely pond and several semi-friendly pelicans (great photo-op, if you can lure one near the fence).There are numerous squirrels on the trees and they are quite friendly and allow people to get very close to them (assuming they carry some sort of food).Give yourself 45-60 minutes to wander in the park before/after visiting the palace.

Happiest incident of my day.. When I was in London, back in 2012, I took the time to walk the city streets on foot just to check out what the city looked like. When I was walking about, kind of lost, I wandered into this park, and it was amazing! Right in the center of London and SO MUCH to see. I spent a good hour in there just seeing the sights. Definitely worth if you've got some time to spare in London.

perfect place for picnic. bring along your lunch box, get a mat, and you can spend your whole afternoon here, with ducks and birds by the pond, beautiful grassland, cute kids playing around you. It is a peaceful place good for breaking out in the middle of the city. As a tourist, I love this place very much.
Quite park in the city center. Quite and nice little park inside the heart of the city. Many squirrels if you bring food (be aware if you are not a big fan of squirrels).

Bring some nuts. Squirrels will love you. . I've been here a few times. But taking someone new is always great.Try pick a day which isn't raining, as although there is nothing as such to do inside the park. Strolling slowing along the footpaths and taking frequent pit stops on the benches is really relaxing and peaceful.The squirrels will love you. They are timid, but if your not loud or clumsy, they will come to you. Have them in your hand or on your knee. Great fun.It is what it is. A park. But the location and scenery make it. Enjoy and don't forget those peanuts. ;)

Lovely park. St James park is one of my favorites. Great scenery and conveniently located. The only downside is there are some cafes with outside seating (you'd think great) but folks please clean up that birds mess on the tables and chairs it's really not nice.

Loved the swans and squirrels. I loved the swans, pelicans and squirrels which were roaming free in the park.Such a lovely place. Would have been better in the summer (I visited during the winter, but it was still great)

My favourite of the Central London parks.. Summer or winter I often try to find time to walk in this park when I'm in the area. It is so peaceful yet full of life. There are places to grab a coffee or snack and plenty of benches to sit back and admire the activity on the pond.
ok. it's a very small park but i had a great time laughing at the ducks/pelicans/etc waddling around and being silly

57 acres of peace and quiet and wildlife galore. We visited this Park when we were in London in March. It is quite large and lovely. It has innumerous birds and ducks swimming and flying around. It has a small lake with two islands and the park itself presents many memorable photo opportunities. Like many of the parks in London it is well maintained and quite lovely.

AN OASIS OF PEACE. For a bit of peace and quiet while in London pop into St James's Park and enjoy the lake, the park and the wonderful wildlife/plant life. The Park is a fantastic place to go to take a stroll away from the hustle and bustle of the city. It has a small lake with two islands, West Island and Duck Island, and these add to the Park's aesthetic beauty. It's perfectly located behind Trafalgar Square and Whitehall and near Buckingham Palace. The surrounding area is full of tourists from every nation and, despite this, is very scenic and tranquil. St James's Park is a wonderful English park, with amazing surroundings and natural beauty. Really it’s an oasis of peace in a bustling city.

Bring bread for the swans. Spread over 57 acres and located adjacent to Buckingham palace, St James parks most endearing feature it the large ornamental lake, which is absolutely stacked with poultry including swans, geese, ducks, waterfowl and various other birds. I would recommend people purchase a loaf of bread from a local convenience store (ie tesco, etc) and bring it to feed these animals, particularly if you have children as they will just love it. For tourists it's best used as a place to come for lunch while in between major tourist attractions in the Westminster area.

take some nuts and you´ll enjoy it a lot. one of the few places in London which captured me so much, I got in love just at the entrance.. just when i got in the park one squirrel jumped on my hand and was staring like ¨you´ll not give me some nuts¨ ... that was very funny) )) I highly recommend it if you want to escape from the crowd and noise of London and just relax your body, your brain...

Sunday Stroll. St James Park was perfect for a Sunday stroll with my young son (19mths) he enjoyed the water, birds, squirrels and the fresh air (as fresh as it gets in London) and Dad could blow off the cobwebs, get a bit of exercise and pick up a coffee from the many vendors dotted through the parks.

"Just about the best park in Central London". Couldn't wait to give this one a review. Seen I've been visiting this place on and off for so many years now.As with the title caption. I would probably have to say in my opinion that this is just about the best of the lot with regards to the Central London Parks.Simply because although it's fairly small (just like the neighbouring Green Park), but slightly bigger. With a lovely lake running lake through the centre. Surrounded by lush grenery and beautiful trees on either side. Plus the addition of various species of wildlife. It's no wonder that this particular park seems to get such rave revues (just talk a walk through at some point on your trip to London and you'll see what I mean).With the additional attractions of Buckingham Palace and Horse Guards Parade at either end. Not to mention some of the views. Which should give you some great shots for your cameras.There is also a number of special events that occur throughout the Spring and Summer months it being situated right next to The Mall. So it can often get cordened off at various times.So try not miss this one out on your visit. As I often find it to be quite a well defined sanctuary from the rest of the various tourist spots in the city centre.

A Welcome Respite From the Hustle Bustle of the City. With throngs of other tourists clogging Trafalgar Square it was a relief to arrive at this lovely and tranquil park. We were blessed with pleasant weather throughout our trip and the days that we stopped in St. James's Park were no exception. There were many beautiful vistas throughout the park that afforded pleasing photo opportunities.The park was clean and well maintained, and we were amused to see stations to store pet waste along the walkways. It appears that pet owners are required to scoop up and deposit any fecal matter that there pets may excrete under penalty of a fine for failure to comply.We watched the ducks, squirrels and pelicans frolic and sometimes beg for treats. They all appeared quite well fed though. We were surprised to see pelicans at such a northern latitude, because in North America we associate pelicans with warmer climates.All in all St. James is a nice place to relax between visits to other nearby attractions such as the Horses at Whitehall and Buckingham Palace to name but a few.t
One of best park ever. Clean, fresh and organized! This park is Really good to read a book, eating something in the grass with the squirrel and doves...or just walk and looking the beautiful views!
Gorgeous. Ducks, Pelicans and and above all the view between Whitehall and Buckingham Palace. After over 50 years of living in London I still find this moving and quintessential
Beautiful Park . This is a really well kept park just moments from the centre of London yet so quiet and tranquil. If you get chance it's a good walk round the park.

Nice Central Park. What's interesting to note about London is the abundance of parks in the city - Hyde, St. James, Kensington, etc. We took a quick walk through St James to Park Mall from Birdcage Walk after Westminster Abbey. Nice fountain, wildlife and café. But wish the park is more brightly lighted at night. Nonetheless it is safe for visitors. During winter, it would not be time optimal for travellers to visit St James on its own but part of a cluster route. Not much of colours to show. A map is really essential to navigate the area. There are signboard maps and directions. If unsure, ask. Londoners are generally helpful.

Lovely to have such a large park in central London. It is an absolute delight to be able to escape from the busyness of central London, and to walk at a leisurely pace in the park. There are food outlets, as well as places to sit and watch others go by. There is a nice fountain and lakes to look at. Do not however encourage the grey squirrels - they are very persistent and cheeky if you let them.

Beautiful - definitely worth the visit. We visited at the end of November, and there were all shades of red, gold and yellow on the trees, which was really nice on a cold winters day.Ducks, swan, black crows and loads of squirrels make up some of the wildlife you can see there. The birds were friendly and will eat out of your hand.Take some raw peanuts with you, still in their shell and the squirrels will love taking it out of your hand and burying it somewhere in the grass.Definitely recommend a visit here, as it's free and a great break away from the city.

stunning and central. way better than hyde park, more charming I meansuper central and good for a quick stroll in the middle of the daytry and find an little house hidden in the park towards big ben/ westminster tube end, it's super cutecycling around it in between attractions can be fun

Just another beautiful park in London!. Nice to go for a walk, run or stroll. It's just something I do after work as it's near from the office. Has nice lakes and lot's of birds to see! It's beautiful.

In my top 3 parks in London. It is a beautiful experience! There are so many beautiful birds and not to forget the squirrels. Right next to Buckingham Palace so if you are near do not miss this park, you will not regret it.

lovely park. a lovely park, complete with a lake, bridge over the serpentine, lots of ducks and geese as well as tourists blocking the paths as they take pictures of the squirrels, obviously eastern Europe does have grey squirrels!

This was possibly my favorite place in London for my family. We had a busy two days that we were able to spend in London. After the changing of the guard (also an amazing experience), we walked across the street and had our packed lunch on a bench. We had our then-15 month old with us and it was a perfect amount of downtime after the chaos of dealing with the crowd watching the guard. Watching the squirrels, diverse waterfowl and bird species was great, and the tiny play area was a really nice bonus for our little one. It was so peaceful (though we did see a helicopter land very nearby--but not at the Palace) and wonderful that I had a hard time leaving, but we had so little time to spend in London. I'd absolutely recommend this to any visitor to the city.It was such a perfect time out from the hustle of our trip.Note: These animals are used to being fed. One woman was feeding the swans and a goose was going through her bag, tugging on her pant leg and generally being quite the persistent bird, while three pigeons landed on her and swans circled too! Not something I'd want, but it was hilarious to watch. She was giggling quite a bit herself, too.

The beauty of it is it's small. Quite a small park compared to Hyde Park, there's a cafe/restaurant in the heart of it. Right next to Buckingham Palace and Westminster Abbey, so if you're touring Central London, don't miss that park!

Absolutely Magical. On my first day in London, I found myself wandering through the peaceful St. James's Park, which is a tribute/memorial walk dedicated to the late Princess Diana. It was a beautiful November day and the light hit the autumn colours of the leaves perfectly. Not only are the different water-birds a sight to see on their own, but the different faces of all nationalities that roam the park admiring the same beauty and tranquility. The park is just of the road from Buckingham Palace, which is then also close to Green Park. I would definitely recommended this St. James's Park walk on a day which may be a little overcast, but with some peeks of sun. Nevertheless, if you don't have time to wait for a sunny day in London -- take the walk anyway!

You must walk through St James's Park. Even in November - this Park is absolutely beautiful. Lots of squirrels who will eat whatever you have right our of your hand. Beautiful birds, ducks, swans, pelicans. The leaves on the trees were changing while we were there which only made it even more beautiful - and the view of Buckingham Palace - well - you just have to see it.

A Peaceful Place Among The Hustle And Bustle. For a bit of peace and quiet while walking along The Mall to Buckingham Palace from Trafalgar Square pop into St James's Park on the left and enjoy the lake, the park and of course the wildlife.
Nice place. Beautiful park with squirrels eating in your hand and other animals. You can take beautiful photographs. Peaceful.
Nice and relaxing park. A very nice park, with several attractions inside. If you love animals, dont forget to bring some nuts. The squirrels there will swarm you and make a good photo
A quiet haven in the city. We were impressed by the tranquil atmosphere in the park and found the friendly wildlife very entertaining.

Beautiful space in the heart of Lodnon. I'm very fortunate to work in the St James's area of London and visit the park regularly and every time I do I find something different. It's always full of people regardless of the season, from cyclists, to sunbathers (deck chairs are available for hire in the summer months) to tourists.The park borders The Mall and Buckingham Palace and it is just stunning to watch how the seasons change. The Park is also a short walk from Green Park (across the road) and within walking distance of the Tube
Love the trees, family day out. Beautiful view of lake, swans and huge trees. It's a lovely place for kids too, they enjoy and you can relax in the shadow on lush green garden.

Really one of the loveliest parks in London. In summer or winter. When I lived in London I spent lots of time wandering in Hyde Park (love the Sunday morning folks at Speakers' Corner), Kensington (my son swam in the Serpentine--wish I had a photo), and Green Park. But my favorite is St James. Now when I return to visit or work I always stay near St James Place, and then walk south to stroll in St. James Park. I was here last December during an extraordinary cold snap--but bore up under frigid temperatures to visit again. Can't wait to return.

A Wonderful Place to Take a Relaxing Break. St. James Park is a beautiful breath of fresh air when you want to get away from the frantic activity of London. The park is beautifully manicured and has excellent gardens and a lovely fountain. You can walk along the river or just relax and take in the flowers and other plantings. The park has large green spaces, but the inviting canvas chairs are for rent by the hour. We didn't see the small sign with the rental information so our relaxation was interrupted by a young man who informed us that if we wish to continue sitting there we had to pay the fee. We thanked him for letting us know and got up and continued to walk through the park.There are many ducks and pelicans in the water and despite signs, people were actively feeding the fowl. There is also a restaurant and coffee shop in the park near the water where you can have a bite to eat or enjoy a cup of tea on the second level, which has great views of the park.St, James Park is conveniently located across the street from the Horse Guard Palace, just a block off busy Whitehall Street. It is easy walking distance from Westminster and Buckingham Palace. If you walk through the park you can end up right at Trafalgar Square and the National Gallery and avoid the crowds on Whitehall.This is a nice place to spend a short time relaxing, enjoying the gardens and watching all the people visiting the park.
Big and Beautiful. St. Jame's Park is so peaceful, and a great place to spend a lazy weekend afternoon. With places to sit with a blanket, it is perfect to enjoy the scenery on a warm fall day.
Take a stroll. Good place to take a stroll and relax when the crowds of London starts getting on your nerves! Plenty of squirrels, ducks and some pelicans to keep you entertained.

A relaxing place to be. I try to visit St James's Park each time I'm photographing in London, as you come down towards the lake near the little refreshment kiosk, when you turn right and walk around there is some grass on your left behind a little metal fence, the squirrels that play on the grass, in the trees are very friendly and approach you. When I first visited in 2012 It took me by surprise but the squirrel began eating out of a tourists hand. In a way the squirrels themselves to me are an attraction and one of the main reasons I go there. It's a peaceful place to be when there aren't tourists all over the place, but even then, you'll be able to find a quiet corner to sit in and read, relax or do as you please. I highly recommend coming to St James's Park and if you have a camera and some seed, have fun and enjoy the friendly little critters munching seed from your hands!Just take a look at the photos I've attached!

Breathtaking!. I thought this was just another park, but I was wrong! I had the pleasure of taking a stroll through here on my way back to the hotel. I was captivated by the natural beauty of the ducks and birds camping on the pond's banks, with the backdrop of the trees in fall. A wonderful sight!!

A Break from the busy city. We walked from Whitehall up through the park to Buckingham Palace on a lovely, sunny Autumn afternoon. The park is a lovely break from the busy city as it is very relaxed and peaceful. Parts of the park reminded me of parts of Central Park in New York as it had the same peaceful atmosphere. There are a couple of cafe stands in the park so you can pick up a drink and a snack.

Truely Amazing Park !!. You really want to take time to visit this Park if you are already close to Westminster Abbey or the London Eye. It has all kinds of fun ducks and geese that you might not see in that kind of setting and variety in Europe as in the St. James's Park. It has a huge long stretched out pond in the middle of the park. There are tame squirrels running around all over the place. It is a place for the whole family for a nice stroll in the sun or a picknick. All around a very nice place to visit. In my eyes a must.
Breathtaking!. I s enjoyed sending time strolling through this park after visiting Buckingham Palace as the sun was setting on our only day in London :)

Pretty. The park is very pretty. You can walk from Buckingham Palace to Whitehall/Westminster area through this park. It's quite peaceful. The geese and ducks near the Eastern edge of the park are experienced at working the tourists for food. It was hilarious. One of them would walk by squawking at people while the other stood a foot back and just stared.

An exhibition in the park - moving experience of France in WW1 and now. Having spent some time on Horseguards, we saw a large exhibition on the edge of the park very close to the parade ground.This had large pictures of WW1 sights, then and now, these were stunning photographs, some of which we could recognise from our Battlefields Tour earlier in the year. Thought provoking, sad and inspiring at the same time with the Guards memorials and the famous parade ground to one side and the rear entrance to Downing Street and the FCO on the other.Not publicised but very glad that we had found it and spent some time in quiet reflection with the thoughts that they provoked
Feeding the squirrels :. ...a huge fun for my godson under the sun ! (and for me too !!). A social squirrel is bound to be fat while the less social squirrel is thin !!

Good place to hang out in the afternoon. If you just need a break this is a good place to hang out, rent a chair or sit on the grass and just chill for a while. Buckingham palace is close by as well as amazing shopping

One of the best walks in London. This is one of my favourite parks in central London. It runs the length of The Mall to the south, and is a very pleasant walk if you want to get from Buckingham Palace (or as part of a walk from Victoria Station) to Trafalgar Square. There is a long lake which you can walk by for the length of the park, and which is home to various waterfowl including swans. The footbridge over the lake offers a good view of Buckingham Palace and is popular for photographs. At the east end there is a café and some lavatories. I do not dally here, but I find it one of the most enjoyable walks in London.

Lovely park. St James park is a lovely park located next to Buckingham Palace and the Household Calvary Museum, so you can see the palace the museum and have a nice picnic in the park. It is a very relaxing and peaceful park, I like the water fountain and the animals are so used to people that the squirrels, ducks, pigeons, and the swans comes to you expecting to be fed, I always take bird food and nuts to feed the animals and my boys loves it and I have taken amazing picturs, there is a small play ground for the kids to play with toilet facilities, and a coffee shop next to it. So this place is ideal for families too.
Squirrel therapy. My favourite place because squirrels climb up me for nuts :-) Also many birds, also as fat as squirrels...
Beautiful park. St. James's Park is a beautiful park located next to the Buckingham Palace. Great place to have a picnic or go for a walk! Open from 5 AM to 12 AM or something like that!

Lovely and relaxing. St. James's Park is a lovely place to stop and stroll about or have a picnic. There is such a nice peaceful atmosphere and the flowers and waterfowl are so nice to see. From here we also got our first glimpse of Buckingham Palace through the trees!

Heavenly. A magnificent Park and it is very nice walk through the gardens and see the squirrels always looking for some food. A very beautiful park to relax in especially coming from a beautiful but chaotic city centre.

Most beautiful varied park. I love strolling in St Jameses. Many kinds of ducks, sort you do not see anywhere else, design of colors and different leaves shapes, shrubs and trees and flowers. In spring they have so many bulbs and amazing quantities of tulips, daffodils etc.

A tranquil place in the centre of London. This is a tranquil place between Horseguards and Buckingham Palace. There is plenty of wildfowl on the lake and at the moment an photographic exhibition showing how the battlefields of WW1 are now part of the landscape of Europe

Warm Novembers Walk. I have been visiting this park for many years now having worked around the area too. It is a great park for couples, singles, walkers and joggers. You can see pelicans landing and swallowing the odd pigeon. Buckingham Palace is not far from this park and St James's Park tube station on the district line is a close 2 minute walk across the road. Green Park can also be accessed by walking up the mall and to the right at the end. Wildlife includes Squirrels, Geese and Pelicans. The sparrows are friendly and will land on your hand if you feed them from the bridge that goes over the St James's Park lake. This is also part of the Diana Princess of Wales Memorial Walk and there are plaques to guide you around the various parks. Worth a visit. This is one of the 8 Royal Parks in London.

Large park with pelicans and playground. We visited this park so that the children could run around after going round a museum. The park is large, with paths around a lake. Some areas of grass could have done with tidying up, and some small stretches of the lake edge were a bit smelly. We saw 4 pelicans, an interesting sight. There were lots of squirrels around as well, they were quite tame. The playground is divided into sections and is great for the children, however it was not possible to sit and keep track of where the children were, as the sections are not all visible from one spot. There were a lot of people, but there is plenty of room for everyone.
Elegant and memorable!. St. James Park takes me back to another point in time. The peace and quiet gives way to thoughts of a more elegant time in history - carriages and long skirts and strolling?

'Beautiful Park'. This is a beautiful park either to spend a few hours in or just to walk through on your way to your next destination. It is perfectly positioned near Buckingham Palace and Horse Guards parade.It's a good size with a small lake area in the middle. Always lots of birds and ducks to see as well as squirrels.Very clean and tidy. There is also a cafe /restaurant in the park if you want to stop for a drink or something to eat.
St James Park. A beautiful park which provided a very pleasant walk in the early evening. It was well maintained and was free from the rubbish that is usually found in most parks.

Beautiful, but full of pushy birds and flocks of tourists. It's hard to fault the park itself, which is gorgeous and well laid out, and for that it gets four stars. But the sheer quantity of tourists in the park - most of which were delighted to be communing with the pushy geese, swans, ducks, pigeons, and squirrels that begged en masse for human food - was a turn off. I spotted only a handful of locals during my stroll, and they were purposefully walking through the park from point A to B. I came here looking for the pelicans, which I finally spotted in the middle of the lake on some rocks, removed from the fray. Oh well. The pelicans' absence didn't seem to bother the tourists. Or the geese.

Perfect spot for nature & squirrel lovers. With a map in one hand and a camera in another we headed towards St James Park, just to be surprised by the beautiful autumn scenes, friendly squirrels and variation of ducks, swans and other beautiful birds around.Dear travelers, get armed with some bread and nuts, go to the Royal St James Park and enjoy life in the most natural way, surrounded by nature and cute animals.

Great. I always love taking a walk through St. James Park. Its so pretty and for being in heart of London, fairly quiet. So many ducks and birds to admire as you stroll along the pond. In the summer there are lounge chairs set up to enjoy the beautiful summer days.
Fantastic park in the heart of London. A lovely park just minutes from Big Ben etc. A great place to go for a break from the noise and crowds.

Beautiful, relaxing place to be!. It's the perfect place to relax with your kids, and show the a little taste of nature, so difficult nowadays. I really love to walk around the park and sometimes is also the perfect place to read a book or write something, and if you love to draw you can find a lot of inspiration here, on Sundays is a little crowded, obviously, but is always ok for me.
Nature in the middle of the city. I love going for a stroll here whenever I am in London. It's so peaceful and relaxing! Definitely worth it!

Nature at it's finest... in London??. Believe it or not this is a great park to simply unwind and release all your worries and stress. Alternatively, if you are touring around London and need to catch your breath this is the place to find solitude. Highly recommend visiting and slowing down from the hustle and bustle of city life.

Lovely Park. St James Park is a lovely park close to Buckingham Palace in London. Very peaceful & serene with a beautiful lake complete with resident ducks. A wonderful place to relax & recharge right in the center of one of the world's busiest cities. Deck chairs are available (for a fee). Another one of the main attractions to see during your London visit. Definitely recommended.

So peaceful. I love this park. The birds are really great and it's laid out perfectly. The tourists are a bit annoying, what with their teasing of the birds, but overall it's great. This is a great way to get away from the chaos in London for a bit, and believe me, you will need some downtown after trekking through this city.

A nice place to be. At James is near Buckingham palace and so is a nice place to sit and enjoy a picnic. In the summer it can get busy and you have to pay to sit in the deck chairs. When we went they were giving out free bin liners for people to sit on.

One of the nicest parks. St James's Park is a lovely park that abuts The Mall and Buckingham Palace. It's well worth a visit.It's very green, has a wonderful lake and lots and lots of ducks, swans and the like. And a lovely bridge where you can get a very nice photo of Buckingham Palace.There's also a lovely quaint cottage - Duck Island Cottage - up at the end furthest from Buckingham Palace. It's a little treasure and again makes a wonderful photo. Horse Guards Parade is also nearby and again makes a wonderful photo.It's a nice place to relax and unwind. It can get busy, though, so be aware of that.
Birds and international life. Wounderful oasis in the heart of London! We watched ducks from all parts of the world. In addition, it was nice to listen people speaking very many languages.

One of the best parks in London. A small but very nice park in between Buckingham Palace, the Mall and the Horse Guards Parade. Well worth a stroll while visiting the most famous tourist attractions in London.
Take a Stroll. Make sure you take a stroll through this beautiful park if you are in London. They do an amazing job and keeping the grounds beautiful. The paths are great!
the best park in London. very nice small park in London city. It has a lot of ducks and different birds. Many squirrels. We loved it!!!

Nice park. Worth a walk during a sunny day. Been there with my wife and our 8month son in his stroller. The weather was great so everything looked perfect. We really enjoyed the birds, the water and the whole environment. Definitely worth a visit for a relaxed walk around the park.

Beautiful trees and open areas.. This park is well laid out and is a credit to the gardeners. The trees are lush and green and plenty of them. the gardens are well maintained and look amazing. There were squirrels running around and plenty of bird life. People were sitting in deck chairs which you can hire for a few pounds to enjoy the surrounds. There is a lake which has pelicans and other bird life. Nice place to relax away from the hustle and bustle of tourist attractions.

Great views, super walks. Lovely views of horseguards and Buckingham palace and really interesting circular lake walk with lots of wildlife. Some beautiful planting too. Great restaurant also serving breakfast, lunch and dinner.nice way to escape the crowds.

Stuning view, like a little danube. Nice landscapes, with smiling people from all around the world. All kinds of birds, especially pelicans and swans, which by the way, have been eaten from our hands. Squirrel that eats from our hands and climbs on us :) amazing! Don't forget to take nuts and chips with you for a complete show!
Great Place. Its beautiful park, we walked there everyday while in London for a week. People need to remmember that squirrels bite, we did not have problem but I saw a kid get a bite
wonderful park. We had a sunny day, sat on the lounge chairs, fed the ducks, saw squirrles, walked along the lake. We enjoyed the view towards the London Eye and had a great time.

Best park to feed squirrels. A beautiful park with a small but quiet playground at the end nearest Buckingham Palace. The playground has clean toilets just for the children. Terrific for young children to expend their boundless energy. Lots of ducks and swans, and friendly squirrels. Consider bringing a bag of nuts as St James was the only park among the few we went to (Hyde Park, Regent's Park, Hampstead Heath / Parliament Hill) where squirrels would come up close to feed out of your hand. Definitely a highlight for our 3 year olds. They loved it so much we went to St. James's Park twice in the week we were in London to feed the squirrels and play.
Fantastic!. Probably the most beautiful park I've ever visited inside a city! With many birds and squirrels, that are very friendly to humans. You can even feed them by hand!

For us the best park in London. We were walking whole day and stop in this part was a great experience. The restaurant is fine, but the views, quality of maintenance and surroundings were outstanding.
View from the Bridge. The view from the bridge is amazing. I can't identify the London buildings..so I want to research it! Lovely.

Just a park. This is not exactly a place to go visit if you are a tourist in London. Its just a park with lots of trees and lots of green, well maintained, very quite, and beautifully located near the palace. Nothing much to see here to say that its a great attraction in London, unless ofcourse you want to get away from the city buildings, noise and traffic of the London roads.

What can I say.... I don't know what you can say other than this is a very lovely park which is well attended and a wonderful way to spend some quality relaxation time. To take some time away from the museums, restaurants, shopping, etc. and just lazily (?) walk, people watch and sit was a real trest!

Wonderful walk after touring Buckingham Palace and Gardens. This peaceful and beautiful park extended a perfect visit to the Palace and it's Queen's Gardens. We were there on a sunny mid-September day and the reflections on the water and view back to the palace were stunning. So nice for a peaceful break from hyperactive London. Keep calm!

Stunning. I really wanted to go here to see the pelicans and hadn't realised just how beautiful the rest of the park was. It was a lovely autumn day so the park was busy with people and animals.The squirrels are so tame they will eat out of your hand, as will the swans, ducks and geese. There are so many of all those animals that it feels like humans are outnumbered. The little duck house near the fountain is cute, the flower garden in it is beautiful. Overall it's a lovely walk to go over to Buckingham Palace.

Cheap entertainment!. St James Park is a great place to spend time without it really costing anything. If the weather is good you can just wander through the park enjoying looking at the flowers and fountains, and feeding not only the ducks and swans but also the squirrels. The squirrels are very used to people and will come right up to you and feed from your hands. Remember to take some peanuts in or out of shells (no salt) as they love them. They sometimes eat them and come back for more or they'll go and bury them then come back for more. We had them climbing on our knees and into my bag looking for the nuts. They are really cute and quite friendly. Take a packed lunch and a rug and have a picnic and you'll find the squirrels will come over to you to see if you have any nuts for them.
Great Park. Its not as big and crowded as others (Like Hyde Park) but its great . The squirrels are very charming.

Peace In A Busy City. A magnificent Park, a beautiful stroll to the Buckingham Palace. Then from the Palace, afternoon tea with the Squirrels. We had a couple of beer and a sandwich in the cafe Inn The Park, very nice, very reasonable. Totally enjoyed the wild Fowl and the Squirrels, away from the hustle. Then off to House Guards.

One of my favourite London parks. Really enjoyable and beautiful even in September. The squirrels were very friendly :) and came easily to ask for food. We regretted that we had none. You could see also some ducks and swans. Many benches to sit and relax. I look foward to my next visit.

Squirrels and a sandwich. Really nice walk through the gardens, we found a place to rest a while and have lunch. Also a great place to see the squirrels around the benches always looking for some food left by the tourists.

Lovely break in a busy city. A great thing about London is there is a lot to see in a relatively small area. We had just visited the Household Calvary Museum and Horse Guards Parade ceremony. Just across the street is St. James' Park which in turn leads to Buckingham Palace. The park is a cool refuge with lovely water features. It has informative signs concerning the wildlife (squirrels and birds) you encounter. There are areas where you can rent a sun-bathing lounge chair.

Away from the hustle and bustle. It was nice to walk through St. James's Park away from the hustle and bustle that is London. There is plenty of bird life and squirrels to keep you amused as you stroll along. A very beautiful park to relax in.

Beautiful park, amazing views at sunset. Visited this park at sunset when the sky and lake were painted in astonishing shades of pink and purple. Amazing views in all directions, beautiful birds & friendly squirrels.

Wonderful park but few flowers in September. Very pleasant walk from one end up to Buckingham Palace. We saw pelicans, swans, geese, ducks and a zillion (!) pigeons. There is a lovely stream that runs through the middle of the park. If you want a nice walk, and to get away from the throngs of people near the London Eye, take the Westminster tube stop and walk away from the bridge. You will see Big Ben on your left and after a couple of blocks, the park is on your left. Then you can get back to the tube at the St. James stop, which is located about 2/3 of the way back down the street directly adjacent to the park on the right or walk through Green Park and up the long hill to Green Park Station.
A favorite place. This is one of my favorite parks in London. Walking through is so therapeutic, and there are many other sites in the are to visit as well.

The Best!. I am so proud to have this park in London, I have been coming here since I was a little girl and now I get to take my own children here. We always walk through the Whitehall entrance to stroke the horses, and take bread and nuts to feed the ducks and squirrels, great fun as they aren't shy at all! There is a children's play area with a great sand pit at the far end by Buckingham Palace. Such a beautiful place, flowers are amazing and the view from the bridge over the lake is like a fairytale. A must go, whether you live in London or are visiting, young and old will love it here.

One of my favourite parks. I've always loved St James. Most people prefer Green Park or Hyde Park, but St James is just as good, if not better. You still have everything around you that you need, and it's often not as crowded in the summer. Perfect to walk through in the winter too for a little romantic stroll
Excellent park for visit. I'm enjoying my visit to this park. the park is well maintained with a lot of bird and squirrel. no insect on the grass so you can enjoy to sit on the grass without mattres
Lovely park. I would suggest to take a picnic. Very beautiful park (As most parks in London are). I would have loved to spend at least half a day there if only I had enough time.

A marvelous place for an afternoon stroll. Our tour group was a bit fatigued when we arrived at the Mall on foot, having started the day in Paris, traveled to London on the Eurostar, and spent a good while touring the city by bus. We perked right up, however, when we crossed the Mall, passed through the Marlborough Gate and began to experience the delights of St. James’s Park. By the time we got to the Blue Bridge we were feeling just fine, snapping photos and drawing each other’s attention to various interesting scenes, objects, people, birds, flowers, and what have you. What a wonderful place for a rejuvenating Sunday afternoon stroll!Our cameras got a good workout. The park offers many fine photo ops, of course, but the best ones for my money are the views from the Blue Bridge. If you look east along the lake you'll see Swire Fountain, Duck Island, and the upper half of the London Eye. My wife and I had our picture taken against this backdrop, and it’s one of our favorites. The view along the lake to the west, direction Victoria Memorial and Buckingham Palace, is also dramatic.

Relaxing stroll. Very nice walk where you got to see friendly squirrels and many birds including pelicans! When you cross the footbridge don't forget to look into the water where there are heaps of fish!The self service area of the restaurant (Inn the Park) served pretty tasty food including pulled pork burgers.
Maravilloso. Sitting in the english garden waiting for the sun, if the don´t come You get a tan from standing in the English rain
Beautiful. The bridge provides a wonderful views in both directions. There are bathroom facilities, and a stand to buy snacks and coffee. Overall, a view nice park in a very nice part of London.

Most Beautiful, Serene Park in the World. Walking through this park is so calm and peaceful - every direction and angle is beauty. Definitely bring a camera to snap shots of the queen's swans in the ponds. There are cafes to stop for snacks and coffee. Just walk and find a bench to rewind and take it all in.

A beautiful respite in a restless city. St. James Park is surrounded by some of the busiest thoroughfares in London, but it's a very quiet, calm and peaceful place. I walked through it fairly early in the morning (around 7-8AM) a couple different days, and I really enjoyed the peace and calm. The lawns and gardens are well manicured, and the variety of flowers and wildlife is amazing - way more than I thought I'd see in the middle of a busy city (see my photos for examples). I saw many joggers, walkers and families strolling through the park, but it absolutely did not feel crowded. I'd highly recommend making a visit if you're anywhere near the area, especially if you're feeling frazzled by the hubbub of the city. It'll really calm you down.

Lovely and quiet park. A lovely, quiet green area next to the Buckingham Palace. The little pond, the goats, the squirrels and the athmosphere makes St. James's Park a really outstanding place for rest and chillout.

Really enjoyed our walk here.. After visiting Clarence House we had a walk through St. James Park and what a lovely park it is lots of people enjoying the weather and relaxing in the park. It was nice to see the wild life there too and seen a few squirrels. There are a couple of cafes there too and lots of notices up telling you about the park etc. Our first visit here and we thought it was beautiful.
Beautiful afternoon. Walking in the park is a great way to spend the afternoon, especially when the weather is lovely. Beautiful place.
Elegant. Walking through this beautiful park you can find peace an quiet.Is very clean and health, an ideal place to stay some hours.

A wonderful park with wildlife!. What a beautiful and well maintained park! The greens and wildlife are plentiful, and provided a nice walk down from Buckingham Palace to Westminster. Definitely recommended to walk through this park (from the palace to Westminster or vice versa).

Lovely walk in London's Paradice . I have always loved feeding the ducks here since I was small. Since living aboard its a regular visit when in London. The grass, trees, flowers, the while land scape is just a glimpse of paradise in the heart of London. Wonder for a lovely walk about.

James Would be Proud. An oaisis in the middle of the city - St James park is situated a stones throw away from Trafalgar square and is filled with all manner of birds, from Swans (given to the queen as a gift by the Russian Czar) to many species of ducks. Come down and enjoy the park with a coffee and a smile.

Amazing park. I loved this park, it's like a oasis of peace in the middle of busy London. I could have slaked for hours in the park and wouldn't have felt bored. Vegetation, green, colors, animals, birds, whatever you want you will find in this park. Very well maintained although it's a huge park. You can see ducks, swans, squirrels, pelicans just to name o few of them. Squirrels are very cute and friendly, of you have a bug of nuts with you, you're just became their best friend. I would definitely go back to spend some time in this park every time I get a chance.

Stroll Through A Beautiful Park. We had just left the Big Bend Parliament area and visited the Churchill War Rooms, coming out we crossed the street into St. James Park. It was a lovely day cloudy and about 75F/24C. We took our time strolling along the park looking at the water, flowers, and people. This is a beautiful park and a pleasant way to relax from the tourist crowds. As you walk along the park towards Buckingham Palace you also pass on the right the Horse Guard House that you can also visit.

A London Oasis. Just two blocks from our hotel and the crowded streets and sidewalks of the Westminster area we found St. James's Park. The peaceful walkways, lake, and interesting activities for children and adults alike provided an oasis from its hectic surroundings. There is a lot to explore that we didn't have the time to investigate; however, if all you are able to do is to walk through it and enjoy the sights and quiet sounds, it's worth the trip. We also walked from the theater district back to our hotel at 11:00 -- a twenty-minute walk and felt perfectly safe.

Great place to spend away from the crowds. Spent an afternoon walking thru much of this wonderful park. Peaceful and beautiful with loads of photo opportunities. Well worth a visit if you're in the area. Highly recommended.

well spent day. We spent there lovely time. ST. Jame's Park is just perfest placeto go for picnic, walk or wathever... I visit this place every timewhen I am in London. Is green and romantic, perfect for relax in city full of people.

Amazing . I visited in June last year and it was amazing, after taking in the sights from Buckingham palace we took a gentle stroll down through the park and got an ice cream along the way before ending up at Westminster after having our photos taken with the guards just opposite the park. Also had a friendly chat with the nearby police and sat on their bikes which was awesome! Definitely visit during late afternoon as it's not too hot. Suprisingly not that crowded for such an beautiful place.

Would love to see this park in every season!. Walked through this park from Buckingham Palace towards the Westminster Bridge ending up at the London Eye. Just a beautiful piece of greenery in the middle of the city. Would have liked to spend more time here! There are a lot of benches to rest when walking through a busy city!
A lovely stroll. I went in December 2013 and it was freezing! However it was a beautiful and romantic Park. Every inch so delicately displayed. It is recommended.

Great walk following the Guard. Changing of the Guard Start PointBest place to start is at the Horse guard, see the Royal Guard form up there and follow them to Buckingham along the mall. Cut across the park to Buckingham to beat the Guards. Good Luck finding a good location, Run Fast as you can...Cheers

A beautiful, restful place in the middle of hectic London. St. James Park is lovely and worth the walk through it. London is a very busy, fast-moving city. The parks are bits of nature in the midst of the chaos. St. James is next door to Buckingham Palace, so one can get some nice pics of the palace from the park. The lake, wildlife, and fauna are great.

Charming Park.. Felt like I had gone back in time. This park is a welcome escape from all the bustle of London Town. Take some time out and chill in this lovely park lots of wildlife and you will even see Pelicans and the most adorable squirrels. Deck chairs are available to rent but if you have a blanket just plonk down on the grass and enjoy. Weather permitting!!!!

Beautiful escape in London. This park is BEAUTIFUL! The feeling of escapism is great after walking around the hustle and bustle of London all day is so nice. The park is well kept and relaxing with a cheery atmosphere, and it really is a must-do on a sunny day (even if you don't have much time in London). Just walk through on your way from Buckingham Palace to Westminster or the Houses of Parliament like we did, and you'll leave feeling instantly more calm after spending time among the swans, pelicans and squirrels.

Perfect Escape out of the city. Me and my girlfriend went here in July. It was a beautiful day, full of history.We sat on the bench close to the lake and watched to our amusement 'People do the funniest things' as people ignored the signs and tried to touch the geese by the weirdest means possible.Its a great spot for people watching, with great view of London from the central bridge. Perfect for families, couples and anyone who just wants a time out

My favourite park in London. Talk about the simple pleasures in life are often the best, when I lived in London 12 years ago, this was my favourite park... And now I'm able to bring my kids here too, as we visit this lovely city. The squirrels were my chins favourite pastime in London. My chn are squirrel charmers,. With a bag of monkey nuts in hand they could easily spend the whole day in this park feeding the squirrels. A must do for any family with chn.

The Place to Go. Got to St. James Park for the first time this trip (was in London May 2005 and Aug 2008). I should have realized that the Mall ran alongside it. This is the route of the Changing of the Guards. I was fortunate to catch it on two different occasions - Jul 31 and Aug 21. Both events were a little different but both drew very large crowds (a given in London in August). In Jul I had a chance to walk in the park for a bit. Also walked opposite which is at the rear of St. James Palace. Both the benefit of being with a tour group. I can see why the people of London have enjoy St. James as well as the other city/royal parks for generations. Our hotel in Aug was within walking distance so we were able to walk up there.

Quick escape. If you go on a tour around south bank and then over the Westminster bridge to houses of parliament, big ben, the westminster Abbey and Churchill's war rooms you can end your trip in the St. James's Park. It's a great way to relax after a long walk and it is a great way to also relax your mind because in the park you don't have the feeling of being in a big and bussy city anymore.

Excellent Park. It is so convenient to get to St. James's park. It's likely that you will end up in the area anyway because it is right across the street from the Churchill War Rooms and very near Westminster. It's a good spot to escape the crowds a little and check out the lake with a variety of birds. There is also a Fields of Battle Lands of Peace display of art going on right now that is worth checking out. There are places to buy treats and to sit by the lake and rest. It is an absolutely beautiful park.
Lovely pretty park. Had a lovey walk through the park. Perfect for a London stroll away from the hustle and bustle. Great location for lots of London's main attractions

Best park in london. In my opinion this is the best park in London. We spent a lovely sunny afternoon enjoying the wildlife around the lake and people watching. It is relaxing and has stunning views of Buckingham Palace. The lake is also beautiful and the Pelicans make it stunning.

Great Park Near the Center of London. The family spent about 90 minutes at the park after visiting Buckingham Palace. This is a park with lakes and ducks. The kids 8 and 5 really needed a chance to run after a day of sight seeing. We stopped at a vendor and had some very good ice cream with a choc alone stick imbedded in the cone.
St James Park. Walking through St James Park was wonderful. Wish we would have taken a picnic to enjoy! Maybe next time! Lots if walking !!! Princess Diana fountain and Peter Pan is a must see!

Lovely Park in the Heart of the city. It was very nice to be able to wander through the park, I had never seen a squirrel before and i saw one there! It was a welcome place to relax in the shade after hours walking for hours in the city.

Fields of Battle-Lands of Peace. An excellent exhibition, very interesting and moving, Do check to see if it is coming to near you if you can't get to London, as after St James Park is going on a UK tour starting in Nottingham on the 17th Sept. This is an exhibition not to be missed.
Relax and enjoy. Spend a few hours walking through the park and enjoy the atmosphere, people watch roller skaters, cyclists, joggers, dog walkers and have some lunch at the lake side cafe.
Really beautiful. This park is really great, even it is not a big one. I definitely recomend to visit it. I remember to see some beautiful pelicans.

Very good, like the greenery,and the cute creatures near the lake. By chance I came across this lovely park, it's opposite the Buckingham palace, I was very surprised to see the cute squirrel and wild ducks and birds so friendly with human beings, expecting to take a bite from people who are feeding them.they won't mind pose for pics...lovely walk out there. I really enjoyed.

Nice Park. Walked through this Park and grabbed a cup of tea and coffee.
Nice Park, friendly staff but beware if you want to sit in a deck chair it costs £1.60 per chair.
Nice walk to Buckingham Palace
Lovely Green. This is a very pleasant escape from the hustle and bustle (not to mention smell) of city life. St James Park is a lovely place to relax, unwind and do some people watching.

Is this London?. Have a walk through St James Park and think about whether you are in London or not. From the hustle and bustle of the manic London streets, step into this park and forget you are in London, It is peaceful, relaxing and quiet with gorgeous lush gardens and an array of flowers. Grass could do with more water (a little yellow) but I guess it is summer.
Beautiful park with lots of bird life in the lake. Lovely park. Nice walk through and across the Blue Bridge. Several large white pelicans on a rock, plus lots of coots, moorhens, ducks and geese.
Wasn't too bad of a park.. It was a comfortable walk. I don't think I would go back regularly but it want too bad. Although if you are just going for a quick jog it would be nice

Beautiful Park. Beautiful, peaceful park in the middle of London. A great place to picnic and unwind after a long day of "Touristing" or "Adventuring" as I like to call my travel experiences. As others have said, the best place is the bridge, where at dusk/night, you can look one way and see Buckingham Palace and turn around and see the Tower of Big Ben and the Eye. I never saw this park truly crowded except for on the morning of the Queen's Birthday Celebration, then it was packed.

A peaceful haven in a busy city. Stayed in a hotel very close to this park so took a few strolls here. Very clean park and very peaceful. We bought a very reasonably priced cup of tea from one of the several vendors dotted around and sat watching the ducks. There is also a bar that serves alcoholic drinks next to the lake which looked very nice.From around the park you can view Buckingham Palace, The Mall and Horseguards Parade. There is a large play area for children and there are places where you can hire deckchairs if you simply fancy a lazy afternoon.

Forget you're in central London!. Break up your day sight seeing with a visit to St. James park! Right there in the middle of London with Buck palace, Horse Guards, Westminster and the Abbey, London eye all close by. If the sun is shining a picnic by the lake is great. You'll forget where you are!

Beautiful!. There was a very nice play area for children. The play area has a "children's only" restroom with adult restrooms 5 min away from the play area. There was also a concession stand near the play area.
The rest of the park is nice if you want a scenic, peaceful walk where you might see squirrels, swans and more.

Beautiful peaceful place. Within walking distance of the bustling parts of London this is a wonderful place to sit back and enjoy. You can hire deck chairs if you wish (although they are not cheap) or vie for one of the many park benches scattered around the lake. Well worth a few hours to enjoy the beautiful gardens even if it is crowded.

Beautiful park, funny birds. The park is beautiful and its best place is the bridge: you get to see the Buckingham Palace and if you turn 180 degrees, there's the London Eye. Just great. And the ducks, goats, swans and pigeons are really nice and add up to the atmosphere. The only let down is the poor management of the park, they should take more care of it.

Picinic Perfect!. We went to Mark and Spencer's to buy food for our Picinic. It is across the street from the park. It was the perfect way to enjoy this lovely spot. Nice place to take a break after a busy morning. It is a beautiful park as others have mentioned.

Beautiful green space in a busy capital. We took our kids here to give our 1 year old a run having been coped up in the buggy all morning. The park is beautiful with some lovely planted borders and wide avenues. We loved the birdlife around duck island including pelicans and baby moor hens plus herons. Our daughter also loved the over friendly squirrels! With facilities and eateries dotted around plus views to Buckingham Palace and Horseguards it is well worth a stroll.

Feeding Water Fowl- So Fun. Our hotel was near the park so we walked here often during our two week visit. Negative: very crowded so you can not just let your little one run off. Positive: the varied water fowl are very fun to feed. We spent happy times feeding bread to various geese, swans, ducks etc. My kids don't get to do that back home so they really enjoyed it. The birds enjoyed it too.
Always lovely. An oasis of calm and freshness in the city...people having lunch...relaxing...one of the lungs of the city

The most beautiful park in London !!. This park has an absolutely amazing atmosphere.. It's a must-go in London. Its position near the Buckingham Palace makes it very accessible.. Don't miss it if in London !

Very pretty. This is a pretty park, more manageable in scale than Hyde. We particularly enjoyed seeing all the water birds we don't have at home, although I didn't see the black swans that are supposed to be there. The park did look a bit tired, dry trampled grass and some litter.

Lovely place to escape from the hustle and bustle. Today was one of those extra busy days in London, with Ride London events going on. However, it was still possible to sit quietly and enjoy the lake and the bird life.
A relaxing afternoon. There was plenty to see as well as being able to relax There are a lot of beautiful birds swans and even squirrels to see It is not far to walk to Buckingham Palace
Nice place to rest. This an oasis in the middle of the city. Take some time to just rest. You can just kick back and enjoy. Close to other attractions.
Beautiful!!. Go see the flowers and have a hot dog just enjoying the beauty of the park. A great place to just rest a little or take a walk.
St.James Park. Def a lovely spot for a stroll as u make ur way from Westminster Abbey to Buckingham Palace..Lovely spot for children to run about..very clean park..nice childrens play area..
Nice place to have lunch. Compact and very handy when visiting central London. Plenty of wildlife to feed and relatively quiet. Always seemed to be well maintained and never closes.

simply beautiful!. I liked everything about St. James' Park. It is huge, has a lake with view to Buckingham's Palace and to London Eye, you can feed squirrels (they aren't afraid of you and you can see them really close and take great pictures of or with them), the toilet facilities are good. You can sit in the grass for free, but if you want to sit in a chair you have to pay for it (that is why there are so many available).
A nice Park for a rest or lunch. A nice clean and well used park, we stopped for a rest and refuel, while watching a game of rounders. The water fountain was nice.
Beautiful park. Walked through the park from Westminster Abbey to Buckingham Palace. Clean, well kept. Could have easily spent a few hours just sitting on the park.

Probably the nicest park in London. Love walking through this park when I visit London, Probably the most picturesque of the London parks. Quite compact, with a lovely lake in the middle, plenty of seats to watch the bustle of the world go by. Plenty of ducks, geese, squirrels, and other wildlife to spot. Great views of the city including Buckingham Palace.

Nice place for lunch after watching changing of the guards. Beautiful park for peaceful walk and lunch. We walked a few blocks to Pret A Manger (great place for take away lunch) and grabbed lunch and brought it back to the park.

Beautiful Park, Great Destination. Normally parks are just a stopping point for my family. However, in London, they are such a way of life! We barely ate in restaurants because we just grabbed food and ate in the parks. This one is no exception. You can see all sorts of birds, fish under the bridge, and even great architecture. I loved being able to look right down the water to Horse Guards Parade. It looks like a scene from a fairytale. No joke. I think you can even rent lawn chairs up across from St. James Palace (where Charles lives).

Fields of Battle - Lands of Peace. Just come home from St. James's Park, London, which is hosting a Street Gallery, a collection of evocative photographs by Michael St. Maur Sheil of World War I battlefield sites, called "Fields of Battle - Lands of Peace, 1914 - 1918". It is set outside in the park opposite Horse Guards.Not only are the pictures stunning, they're accompanied by interesting and enlightening text and some fascinating images of the War. Not to be missed!The official launch is on August 4th, to mark the outbreak of the First World War and the exhibition will remain there until Armistice Day on November 11th.Organizer Chris Bridge, whom we met by chance, is delighted with the help and support given by the Royal Parks.
Just right next to Westminster. The Royal park that you do not want to miss, adjacent to the Buckingham Palace. Good for a stroll in the day time. Get some shades in summer.

Perfect views, perfect location. If you are short on time and can be in only one park in London, this should be it! It is small enough to walk around and its location near all the Central London landmarks make it very convenient. It is clean and well maintained as well. Really this should not be missed.

Gorgeous. We walked through this park as often as possible while staying in London. The bird pond was beautiful, and the park was just generally a great place to spend time. A nice calm place in the busy city.

Safe, overly sanitized park. This park is near the center of London surrounded by gvmnt buildings. As such it is very safe and has no character. It is filled with tourists and locals trying to get their natural sun tan. Make sure to try their 4.5 hot dogs (7.5 usd). They taste exactly like a 1-2 dollar hot dog in central park, NYC, except they cost 7 dollars.
