Excellent way to exercise in London. Loved the open space of the park. There is of wild life to see, but beware of the squirrels, they will climb up your legs to try and get food. There are hundreds of mature trees to admire and we were there when the daffodils were blooming. Walk through the park from Park Lane through to Buckingham Palace.

Walk through the park. We visited London to see a show on the Saturday night (Tailor Made Man) and decided to walk through St James's Park on the Sunday morning on our way from the hotel to the coach station. The day was not the best weather and in that muddy unattractive time just before Spring really kicks in so probably not seen at its best. However, it was pleasant enough due to the wildlife that lives there. We saw numerous birds including a heron and loads of tame squirrels that were eating out of people's hands. We also saw some interesting wildlife in the form of a runner who decided to do pressups with his feet on a bench - funny as only his head was going up and down not his torso! We finished by Buck House end and that's always good to see on a trip to London. Would we rush back - no, but it made a necessary walk more pleasant.

Beautiful but busy. One of my favourite London parks. Lots of birds, usually some squirrels, and a nice cafe to get food if you need it. Best in Spring / Summer when there's more bird life.Usually very busy as it's quite close to Buckingham Palace. Go to Green Park for a bit more space to spread out if you're planning to stop for a picnic.
What a wonderful Park. The children really enjoyed their day visit here, it is a lovely park right in the middle of London.

Did I miss something?. I see all the delighted 5 star reviews. Yes. It's green and close to Buckingham Palace. It is convenient to walk through St James Park to get from Buckingham Palace to the Churchill War Rooms Museum. I did just that. Maybe it is because I'm from New York and know Central Park. Central Park is 5 stars. St James is no Central Park. But like I said it's convenient to cut through the park after leaving Buckingham Palace if you don't want to walk straight down the Mall.

Beautiful. It was just beautiful. I loved walking thru this park, seeing all the birds and squirrels and taking in the fresh air. Even though it was cold, it was still fun! We also had a glimpse of Camilla as she was passing by in a car.It is very relaxing, you cannot visit London, without having to visit this park!
Great Run. I put in a few laps around the Park and loved every minute (minus the cold wind!). It's a lovely place to collect oneself in the midst of a hurried vacation.

Pretty place,fresh air in UK. Talking about St.James place was make me missing the time when I was visiting UK for a course.On the summer time,around afternoon tea will be many people there,would be lovely if you visiting in the morning time when not to many people around.Best place for a walk,fresh air and the park well maintain,inside the park there is small shop for snack/sandwich:good enough.Put St.Jame's park on your list if you visiting UK,you would not regret
just perfect. this park is fantastic,just across from Buckingham palace,and 5 minutes from Big ben.The grass look perfect,and all the flowers

Awesome. Really nice park, well looked after and the squirrels ! Oh my god the squirrels ! So cute, they come right up to you and eat out of your hand ! Definitely a place to see, can't wait to go back !
Beautiful!. Flowers blooming, dog running, people meandering - a great park on the way to Buckingham Palace. Quite lovely.

an oasis of green. A real nice and well tended park with enough space to have a walk or to take some time to rest after walking aal the streets. When spring will come the trees and plants will give some nice effect to the surrounding buildings.

Wonderful!. In the centre of London, near the Buckinham Palace, th SSt. James Park offers to its visitors the opportunity to relax, to walk pacifilly, to see different kind of birds...It is simply excellent.
Squirrels. St. James's Park is a wonderful place to wile away a couple of hours. Our favourite thing was to feed the squirrels almonds. They come right up & take the nuts from your hand.

St. James's Park. A good place for a walk, if you want to feel like a local person from London. Good to see different kinds of birds along the Lake such as pelicans and ducks. While I was here, Spring is around the corner..Flowers are starting to blossom, which gives the Park a nice feeling to it. Very safe and lots of people walking around. Very close to Buckingham Palace and Horse Guards Parade.
Pretty Park. It was a simple park but very lovely. If you are going to be near it take a look otherwise don't go out of your way just for it.
A beautiful park in the heart of London.. Really amazed about this park full of creatures like squirells and many types of ducks and birds.Very relaxing place compared to the busy Oxford str.
Lovely Walk. Beautiful place to stroll thru! Squirrels will eat from your hand Ducks, Geese and other birds. You can walk to Buckingham Palace from the other side of the city.

Heart of London. A shortish walk from Victoria Station, surrounded by grand and official London, St James's Park is a lovely oasis of greenery, water and birdlife. On a sunny day, the pleasure is just in being there.
St James Park. This is not much of a park and not much of a walk. Rather uninviting and dreary. However, it is right by the palace.

Favourite London Park. Love walking through this delightful and beautiful park I. The heart of London. Few parks offer such a range of iconic London views surrounded by wildlife, tourists and business people going about their everyday lives. Take a seat and watch the world go by!

Summer afternoon OR winter wonder land. A special place to find some peace and quiet in the middle of one of the busiest places in one of the world's busiest cities...Picnics about during the working week - find hedgies, PE's and PA's taking in the sun in summer and marathon hopefuls treading the tarmac mill in winter...Go see, take a breath and consider the history...

Good picnic/rest site - a lovely park. I had to walk through the park today and was reminded how great a place this is in the summer to take a break from sightseeing. There are a number of small independent sandwich shops near Victoria street - or bring your own. Sit down on the grass, take in the view. There is a small playpark for kids at the end near the palace. Take a walk around the lake - look at the peclicans. If you're sat down quite often you can end up being pestered by squirrels. A good rest stop between the Buckingham Palace and Houses of Parliament/Westminster Abbey/War Rooms, worth the walk from Trafalgar Square through Admiralty Arch.

Relaxing atmosphere with great birds. I love walking through St. James Park and looking at all the squirrels and esp. the beautiful pelicans that live there! In one direction you see Buckingham Palace and in the other direction you see London Eye. There are normally quite a few tourists because it is a popular place! When it's warm, you can relax on the grass :)

Still a firm favourite of ours. The park is quite small, well maintained, and located between Downing Street/Parliament and Buckingham Palace. It takes just ten minutes to walk between the two areas, unless you have a six year old son who stops to talk to the numerous free roam birds and squirrels that follow you through the park. So, get off the tube at Parliament, check out Big Ben, the Abbey, and Downing Street, before heading through Horse Guards Parade and through St James Park to Buckingham Palace. Check on line and try to time the walk to coincide with the changing of the Guard at the Palace. There is a restaurant in the park but we didn't have time to visit it.

One Of My Favourite Royal Parks. So pretty, great trails to walk, benches to sit, and grassy areas to lay a blanket out to read or picnic! I love this park and it's so centrally located. Must stroll through at least after you say hello to Big Ben :)

Respite in the Middle of the Mayhem. Just steps away from the throngs outside Buckingham Palace is the green and peaceful sanctuary of St James's Park. Meander over the lovely foot bridges, admire the views from all directions, enjoy the ducks, geese, and swans that waddle across your path. It's my favorite way to cross Westminster.

Great park, lots of birds!. This is a nice park to walk about in after strolling past Buckingham or on your way to Buckingham as opposed to walking on the Mall. The entire park itself is quite beautiful, though the copious amounts of birds make it a little hazardous as they fly over! The birds are also what make it special, I think. There are over 40 types of birds in the park - even pelicans - so you'll see quite a few. Also, it can get really packed with tourists, so there's that too.

No visit to London without this park.. We always go to this park on our first day in London. Be sure to buy a loaf of bread before so you can feed all the birds.Great views from the bridge towards Buckingham Palace and Whitehall and The London Eye.

Great place for a run!. The park is so pretty and a great setting for a run. Set right at Buckingham Palace, the Royal Horseguards and London Eye you can catch a glance of in the distance. Lovely lovely park. :0)
Welcome park in the City. Lovely just to wander round or use as a walk through to Buckingham Palace and Horseguards Parade and enjoy a picnic in the warmer months.
Cold and long!. At this time of year itis super cold in London, so bring a nice warm jacket you will need it and comfortable shoes since it is a long walk.
Have great simple lunch. Great simple lunch at St James's park at the 'Cafe In' in the terrasse. Comming from Buckingham palace.
Beautiful Scenery!. What a great walk on the way to Buckingham Palace! The area was well maintained and very peaceful at 9AM. I could hear the marching guard and the birds were singing!
Great afternoon out. Had a great afternoon out with my wife. After a long day of site seeing we relaxed in St Jame's Park and rested our tired feet!

My favourite London park. I walk through St James's Park whenever I can. Best to start at the bottom end near Horseguards' Parade and look for the pelicans who are usually on the rocks. Then walk up the park on the right hand side of the lake to see all the various birdlife. Go onto the bridge halfway up and enjoy fantastic views of Whitehall at the bottom end and Buckingham Palace at the top. There are sometimes concerts in the bandstand in the summer and on a hot day, rent a deckchair and snooze the afternoon away under the trees.

Who knew that pelicans have lived in St James Park since the 1600s?. London's parks and open spaces are so often taken for granted. St James Park is home to an amazing variety of wild fowl, including the unexpected pelicans. Sitting on a bench in the spring sunshine watching the world go by while resting your weary feet - what a treat. And it's all for free.

Spring stroll. Like all English parks it is so spacious and gracious, that one does not mind the crowds, from the world over, all in ecstasy about black swans, coots, ducks and the gorgeous gates of the Palace. Spring is in the air, snowdrops and blossom buds.

Oasis of Calm in Central London. A little park in the middle of London, between Buckingham Palace and Westminster, it is an oasis of calm and greenery. The view from the bridge over the lake of either Horseguards/Whitehall or Buckingham Palace is worth a photo for tourists and hobby-photographers alike. There are lots of places to sit down and there are usually a couple of tea/coffee stands, too.
Winter's Day.. Lovely park. A relaxing way to spend an hour or two walking through the park and feeding the squirrels. Remember to take some nuts for great photo opportunities!

St James's Park London. A very enjoyable walk through the park, great for children as they can see the squirrels up close. Stroll at your leisure and enjoy the scenery, away from the hustle and bustle of London
Building site. Walked through the park but its currently undergoing repairs due to the 2012 olympics. Lots of areas fenced off. Still enjoyable and lots of squirrels about wanting feeding.
Tranquil oasis in middle of a large city. Nice place to escape to with a book when the sun is out, can get a bit cramped around lunch time but you can always find a spot
very clean and tidy. walked through st james on way to buckingham palace. lovely and pretty and everyone polite brings the best out in londoners

A beautiful stroll inside inner london. A lovely place to spend a couple of hours strolling around admiring the park, looking over the lake at the palace sitting feeding the ducks, geese, swans and pelicans. A lovely place.
Good place for lunch. We went to Inn the Park for lunch and would highly recommend it. On a bitterly cold day the hot apple drink was welcome and the food delicious.

little piece of heaven in the city. I used to run through this park ay lunchtime with my freind from shell. It was so clean and well kept. Everyone is always really friendly and it gets really busy in the summer months.
fun with squirrels!. be sure to go with some bread! my girl won't forget this tricky squirrel looking around in their backbag ...relaxing break during the day....and facilities (free toilets)

Nice for a stroll in Central London!. Just great to have this park in the middle of the city - so relaxing - even in the winter, but absolutely wonderful in spring and summer - very well maintained - always a joy to spend time there!

Wow - stroll through history. This park is so beautiful, especially in the spring with the flowers. Look for The Diana,Princess of Wales Memorial Walk - a 7-mile circular walking trail in London dedicated to the memory of Diana, Princess of Wales. From Kensington Gardens, Green Park, Hyde Park and St. James's Park in a figure-eight pattern, passing five sites that are associated with her life: Kensington Palace, Spencer House, Buckingham Palace, St. James's Palace, and Clarence House. Walk AROUND, not THRU, the park at night, though.

Scenic. This park is in the heart of London and very scenic to walk around, relax, have something to eat or simply take lovely photos. If you stand on the bridge with your back to the Palace, the view is like something from a fairytale. You'll see loads of squirrels hoarding their nuts. Beware of the swans, they look beautiful but get too close and they'll bit. You can cut through this park to get to many places, Trafalgar Square leading to the West End for instance.

see the squirrels!. Such a great park, so pretty and full of wildlife. See the ducks on the pond, squirrels so tame they will eat nuts out of your hand and there is a cute kids playground with sandpit. Sometimes you can hear a brass band on a Sunday and there is deck chair hire, a cafe and ice-cream stand. I love this park it's gorgeous
Cosy. A nice place to take a walk, not so huge as Guide Park. ideal for a couple of hours rest. A very lovely park.
just to walk through. It is a great place to just walk and clear your head. I haven't seen so many animals in a city park before visiting St. James's Park.

The best park in Central London. Its a delight to have this wonderful park in the middle of all the sites of London - its between Trafalgar Square, Buckingham Palace and Westminister Abbey and the houses of Parliament. It has a lovely cafe in the centre of the park and some lovely ponds and a lovely bridge over the ponds that has a great view of the London Eye. You'll enjoy it.
It's ok. Don't know what to say about it, other than it's a park. Nice to get a bit of greenery, but I wouldn't dwell...walk through on the way to Buckingham Palace or to Victoria Street.

Nice to sit and chill whilst watching the very amusing wildlife.. Despite it being a very cold day it was nice to stroll around park and stop off on a bench every so often and watch the birds and squirrels .

Lovely. I enjoyed my morning walks through St James park during my recent stay in London. Well-manicured and clean, the Park offers a view of the London Eye on one end and Buckingham Palace on the other. There were also some interesting waterfowl to see along the way.
A must. Lovely park to visit, especially in the spring and summer. Nice to have a break from the fast pace of London if visiting the capital is a bit overwhelming

Great park.. The park is just in front of Buckingham palace. You can just walk on the side or get inside and spend hours.
Nearby there is a bicycle rental... you can rent a bike and ride aroudn the park or the city.
Inside there is a nice restaurant.
Beautiful!. Lovely Park with an old world feel...yet full of new life! Spent about 2 hours walking around and totally loved every minute. Worth the trip.

Beautiful Park!. We went in March and though the weather was a bit chilly, the entire weekend we were there it was bright and sunny. It made for a great walk in the park to slow down the pace of running around trying to fit in as much as we could in two days. They had a marathon going on as well as a concert and street vendors nearby which added to the atmosphere.
nice, and elegant.. Is very nice, elegant, is easy to travel them is nice to walk St.Jamesstrett , the most exclusive shops where presuntly the Quenn byed.the tube has a station there.
Cosy and nice. A lot of life, even in January. Different types of birds, a lot of tame squirrels. Recommened for travelers with young children. Nice restaurant in park. Had tea and soup of the day.
If you love parks.... If you love parks, this one is one of the most beautiful in London, even during winter time. Good attraction to spend 20 minutes or 4 hours.

Worth several strolls. The park is wonderful for many reasons - it's landscaping, waterfowl, beauty, water features, views, people watching, proximity to Buckingham Palace and Westminster. There's a terrific café in the park. Watching children revel in seeing the many types of waterfowl was enjoyable.

Beautiful Park. I recently read that Churchill liked to walk through St. James Park. He knew what he was doing because it is a beautiful park with much wildlife, greens, and pathways. It also ends at Buckingham Palace, so it is well worth stopping through.

Great scenic route to Buckingham Palace. Great scenic route to Buckingham Palace and a little bit of country in the city.This is a great route from Horse Guards Parade or Trafalgar for those with Families and small children as you can let them run and have a little bit more freedom compared with walking down the Mall and having cars to the side of you.

Charming even in winter. We took a brisk walk through the park on our recent stay in London and even though it's winter, there was lots to see: majestic pelicans, various ducks and birds, loads of squirrels and spring flowers slowly making their appearance. The park provides a delightful rest from London's hustle and bustle.

Bird lover's paradise. For me London's most attractive park. Mainly dominated by the large natural looking lake. Home to many varieties of birds all eager to entertain at the offer of food!
Nice cafe/restaurant.

Lovely park. Really lovely park with views of Buckingham Palace and looking the other way the London Eye. I was just cutting through but enjoyed the views and took a couple of photos. Pretty even in winter.

An excellent place!. Wish we could have a same place in Tokyo!
It's a very quite, beautiful park even in the center of London. We love it!

Wonderful for bird-lovers. All London's parks are lovely - this is no exception. There is a huge variety of birds on the lake - with boards explaining what they are. There is a large cafe overlooking the lake.A stroll through the park brings you to Buckingham Palace or Horseguards Parade (by Downing Street) or you can wander back up The Mall to Trafalgar Square. Lovely - even in February.

It's gone to the birds.. I had a great time spending the better part of the afternoon walking through St Jame's and taking in the sights. It was a great reprieve to have this large park in the center of the city. It was filled with water and trees and of course the birds, so many birds (I am referring to variety and just general quantity as well).

London is also many amazing parks. This Park is surprising, it's located in the very heart of London just a few minutes walk from Buckingham Palace, and it's a must see for everybody passing by London. It's full of natural life and having a walk around is an amazing experience by itself. Take a seat on a bench and enjoy birds all around, you shouldn't feed them as clearly remarked on signs, but as far as I could see there are so many people who simply cannot resist.

Park yourself for a picnic... The very heart of the real London. Behind St James Place - next to Buckingham Palace - five minutes to Waitrose Belgravia - ten to Harrods. Treat yourself to some posh take-away from either - and a rug from your hotel and slot yourself into the heart of London history. And then join the ghost of Ian Fleming at his favourite bar. You'll have to do a bit of spying to find out which that is - but it's only minutes away....

Beautiful park. St James's Park is a beautiful London park. There is plenty of wildlife, a few water features, great views of Buckingham Palace and of Horse Guards Parade. The location is so central it also means you can visit lots of other attractions close by - Buckingham Palace, Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey, the National Portrait Gallery and the National Gallery, Trafalgar Square, etc. etc.

A little piece of heaven in central London. On of my favourite parks in central London- whether rain or shine and a nice cut through from Picadilly to Westminster Abbey, Bucks Palace etc. Beautiful flowers and fountains and a great cafe and restaurant. Check out the ducks, pelican and ( very obese and tame) squirrels.

A walk. We walked from Bayswater through Kennsington Gardens, Hyde Park, Green Park and then St James park. Thought the park was well kept and still looked nice in February. There were lots of birds to look at and we especially enjoyed watching the Pelicans.Don't understand though why the little refreshment stops do not have tables and chairs or maybe they do in the Spring/Summer months. The day we walked through the park was 'springlike' in February and we would certainly have stopped for a drink had there been somewhere near the kiosk to sit.
Beautiful. The gardens were amazing, we saw it in summer and the flowers were amazing, the river was lovely, definitely a must see!

Good for geese - and pelicans. Unfortunately, it was raining when I visited the park. There's certainly enough wildlife to interest bird-watchers - mergansers, shelduck, bar-headed geese, as well as the famopus pelicans. However, the park, like its neighbour, Green Park, is looking a rather sad, muddy expanse at the moment - understandably perhaps, in view of the wet weather.

Lovey winter walk. I expected a shabby, tourist-ridden walk and got a delightful stroll in a beautiful setting on a classic, cold, sunny winter's day. Superbly laid out, exquisite views in all directions - Buckingham Palace (of course), the buildings lining the surrounding streets and the lake itself - not at all crowded and a pleasure to be there. I'm not aware it gets any headlines within London's list of attractions. It should. The staff should be very proud - this is a lovely part of a great city.
Beautiful park. We strolled through on an evening before dinner. The animals are so used to people they are not afraid to get close for pictures. Takes the busy feel out of London .
Spot the birds!. If you would like to indulge in some leisurely bird spotting this is the place for you. A pleasant stroll on a good day.

Always pleasant to walk around but... The new memorial to the police is very unattractive. Has it been built to mask an underground train air vent? For some reason it hums, like a fridge. The monolith looks like it is made of corrugated plastic, although on closed inspection is made of glass. Luckily, the memorial is not central to the Park and so does not spoil its look too much!
St. James's Park. Wonderful place to stroll. Many of the locals out in groups enjoying lunch and a bottle of wine or brew. Very friendly environment

Superb.. Beautiful park, many flowers, birds, people. You can walk through it either on your way to or from Buckingham Palace. If you like photography, it provides you with beautiful backgrounds. Also it´s location is great when your sight-seeing on foot in London. And if you need to, there are bathrooms available.

Loved the squirrels. My daughter and I had never seen squirrels before so we really enjoyed wandering around this park. We spent 5 days in London and visited here 4 times. There are toilets, a cafe and a children's playground, also lots of benches to sit on.

england at its best. well what else would one want from a Royal Park. Walk, run, skate, stroll, chill. This is a fresh lung for those in London. enjoy the princes Diana walk around the park, just enjoy,
Great. Great place for chilling and winding up. Even better when spending summer nights with a bottle of wine and the loved one.
Peaceful. Love London parks all that greenery and it gets you away from the hustle and bustle of city life. If the weather is good try and spend some time there to recharge

A lovely walk in the heart of London. Visited the park on a lovely spring day on a walk through London, so saw it at its best, the perfect way to get from the Palace of Westminster and the Abbey to buck house, pelicans, geese and squirrels abound as well as a nice looking cafe. Although very popular there is a sense of peace and relaxation, followed by a watch of the guard changing and a trip back down the mall with a diversion through horse guard s before back to Trafalgar square and on to the west end.Well worth a walk.

Fantastic!. We were only there for 25 minutes as we walked from Buck Palace to our Duck Tour, but the kdis were fascinated. Loads of ducks of all varieties, squirrels and magpies everywhere. Not too crowded with people either. Just lovely.
Fantastic. Fab place to spend those quiet moments. Love jogging here or just rewinding the day. Only downside no shelter to hide if it rains..

A Romantic Walk. My new hubbie and I walked through St. James Park just before noon on a weekday. It wasn't too busy. There's tea/coffee//snack stand by one of the entrances-we got tea. There's a lake-bridges to walk over it. Birds-ducks and geese. We went in January so it was cold and damp, but there is a lot of grass that I would imagine would be perfect for laying out in better weather. There were plenty of park benches to stop and rest/read if that's your thing. Its a large park, perfect for a stroll.

lovely place to stroll. This is worth a visit-vast Park in the middle of London with lots to see, We were there in June and it was very busy but the Lady in the booth at the entrance had ;lots of details. would recommend
lovely walk. In the heart of London you get this tranquil and beautiful park with some fantastic views - take a photo on the bridge looking towards Horse Guards
Good. A great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Nice and peaceful. spend atleast 1 day of my week reading a book at this park. love it.

What a peaceful park. I have been amazed how you feel at peace in this park... all the animals are used to be fed by the londonians so they are not affraid of the humans, they come very close to you and the squirells eat in your hands! In 3 years living in Canada, I have never seen a squirrel that close!Perfect for a sunday afternoon. Really charming
Great. great for spending an evening with the family. relaxing atmosphere with plentiful to do in plentiful space.

Winter weather. As grandparents we were disappointed not to be allowed into the Princess Diana childrens playground withou a child, Surely this is over the top when unaccompanied children are not allowed.

The nicest shortcut in town. We actually were never supposed to get in the middle of St. James': struggling to find our way back to Trafalgar Square (first time in London)... Ok. then there was one of the most beautiful sites in town.. Wonder what it looks like in the daytime:-)

Lovely Park. Had a walk through the park after visiting Buckingham Palace and then down to Houses of Parliament.
Lots of wildlife - swans, pelicans, squirrels - brilliant walk

Great place to walk about on a sunny day. We have taken the walk in St. Jame's Park over the weekend and it was really interesting with some birds and the ponds around. The views are amazing and the park is well looked after. It connects to various royal houses so it was quite a nice day out to be enjoyed the quieter side that London can offer... :)

My favourite Park in London. We always make a point of visiting St James' Park in London when we are there. It is a delight, a green oasis from the hustle and bustle of the city. Take your lunch and a drink and sit down on one of the park benches and watch the world go by. Even better, take a packet of almonds and feed the squirrels, they will run up your leg and along your arm and sit in your hand while they eat a nut. It is fascinating for children and adults alike. At one end sits Buckingham Palace and the other the Cabinet War Rooms and Horseguards Parade. Along the sides are Birdcage Walk and Pall Mall - the park is something not to be missed. There is plenty of bird life also and with a few crumbs you can become "bird man" and literally have the pidgeons eating out of your hands. Close by is also the Guards Museum which is certainly worth a visit.

An oasis in central London. With extraordinary views of Buckingham palace, the facilities like the cafes makes this on a sunny day even in winter a special place to visit!! It's incredible as you can always seem to find a quiet corner to relax and enjoy the views

This park is so close to Buckingham Palace. I love this park,it has grounds which you can sit have picnic,also so close to Buckingham palace we went there first then pass where the soldiers stay into the park had lovely few hours there.In the park is a lake with ducks on it fish in it. Swings for kids and plenty of places to walk and sit there is also two cafes for hot/cold drinks.

One of the best London parks........ Great park, with plenty of snack/coffee places. Very well kept, and is great to walk around the pond - plenty of water fowl to look at. There is a sand pit / swing play area (with coffee shop and kids toilets immediately nearby).Well worth a visit.

My favourite Central London park. I quite often try to go via this park if in the middle of London. I used to work nearby for years and it was always a pleasure on a sunny day taking a sandwich there and finding a spot in view of the lake. One time a few of us from work had a slightly boozy lunchtime picnic in the park that lasted until evening.

The Wildlife.. A wonderful place to just be. Walking through here is great if you love nature and people! as l do. The incredible amount of different birds that migrate through the park unseen elsewhere in London are seen here. Take some seed and bread and take time. There is a vast lake too where swans, ducks and moorhens and more settle waiting to be fed. On the edge and cafe/restaurant to while away hours. A beautifully kept park with so much to offer and see through the seasons. I loved it here and the views of the city arounds you is terrific too, a stones throw from Trafalgar sq and Horse Guards Quarters. Fabulous Time if you take time. Go, go on! what are you still reading this for!

A wonderful park!. After seeing the Change of Guards at the Buckingham palace we proceeded on foot in to St,James park- a wonderful place for walking- green grass, ducks and swans, squirrels ( take some nuts with you to treat them), river running through it! We were very lucky with the weather, it was a clear sunny day and we did wonderful pictures of London sky exactly from that park! Have a nice walk there!

Covered in snow. We walked through here on the back to our hotel from Piccadilly Circus. It was beautiful and pristine in its blanket of snow. There were families playing and children laughing, the fountain in the lake spurting away there, providing a lovely frame down to Buckingham Palace.
Lovely park full of natural life. Even on a freezing winter day, its beauty and fauna -specially visiting migrating birds- will catch the eye.
A WALK THROUGH ST. JAME,S PARK. serene atmosphere, outstanding cleanliness,easy access to main sight seeing facilities in London. a walk from the palace to Piccadily road is recommended.

haven. There is nothing I dislike about St James Park . As we live in a country location, its home from home, with a muliitude of wild life yet with many people out for a stroll, then with buckingham palice & westminster each end of the park its just beautiful haven in the city .

A Thing of Beauty is a Joy Forever.... Walking along the pond in St. Jame's Park to see the birds, the flowers, and the Horse Guards Parade reflected in the shimmering water is a ritual delight for me, and has been for nearly forty years. Sherlock Holmes fans will see the same view today that inspired artist Sydney Paget 125 years ago. Wonderful!

Snow in St. James's Park. We were lucky to visit London with this weather. St. James's Park is absolutely beautiful and peaceful covered in white.Full of squirrels and birds walking around. Simply stunning.
lovely. this was a nice place for the kids to run around, very nice around the water area, loads of squirels
Nice park for a short walk. Very nice park in central london, spent a bit of time walking round before visiting St James Palace.
St.Jame's Park. This great place to go with family and friends around the park. Its huge park with some facilities. It has lake with ducks and people can feed them..anyone can visit here.

Look out for the Pelicans!. Lovely, peaceful park near Buckingham Palace.
Always plenty of squirrels running around, and if you're lucky you may see the Pelicans! One gentleman was sitting on a bench with a pelican and stroking it like it was a pet, he let passersby have a go too - at no cost of course! Random, but quite hillarious!
Nice place to wander. Just between Buckingham Palace and The horse guard parade a nice place to wander during a winter morning watching at the lovely squirrels
peacefull walk. had very enjoyable and peacefull walk through the park after watching the armistice day parade. plenty of wildlife, squirrels etc and birds along with the ducks

Squirrel heaven. The park is a welcome respite from the hussle and bustle of the shopping streets and major tourist attractions. Pretty sizeable park with a large lake which is home to a few pelicans and lots of geese. There are plenty of squirrels who are so cute and friendly. Make sure you take nuts along to feed them with. There is a cafe at the bottom end of the park i.e. furthest part away from Buckingham Palace with indoor and outdoor seating.
lovely. even in january it is well kept and lots to explore..and alot of people out enjoying even a chilly day in the midst of downtown london. well worth the walk
A green & pleasant park. Nice oasis & contrast to Piccadilly, Regent St, etc. Reminded by Peter Ackroyd's "biography" of London that it has more park land than almost any other major city.
What a beautiful place. This park is just great, so green and luxurious, felt like a king walking through it, not to be missed.
Nature walk. Loved its location and as I am a keen photographer it was great getting the chance to photograph squirrels and all the different birds.

Beautiful Park. Can't wait to see this park during the spring/summer. It was a little winter dreary but London parks are so well kept and manicured I am sure this park is stunning during warmer seasons.
Cosy little park. Squirrels everywhere. I mean all over the place. Pesky little creatures. Maybe they could sell food to feed them.

St. James's Park. By far my favourite park, well kept and stunningly beautiful. I will soon revisit with my family when going on a Kings and Queens Tour with London Premier Walking Tours, which I am really looking forward to.

Bring peanuts to feed squirrels.. All the parks around London are great, but they are even more fun when you bring the 'monkey nuts' or unsalted peanuts still in the shell to feed the squirrels. The UK doesn't have rabies, so you can feed the furry critters and not worry about getting bitten - plus they are tame because everyone feeds them!

Take a break in the park. What's not to like about St. James Park? It's an oasis in the scrum that is the center of London. When your feet have surrendered from walking from Piccadilly to Covent Garden and back, take a break. Check out St. James. Remember that you'll have to pay for using the convenient canvas recliners that dot the green. Don't be surprised when the ticket seller appears. It's worth it. Watch the world go by and recharge before charging off for another round of "must visit" stops. Try to visit in the spring when daffodils are sprinkled about. Magic.

great park in town. best location in central London, great park to just chill out, stroll, rest or jog. beautiful small lake view, squirrels around to add cheerfulness. best for family day and children playground

Ideal for photography!. When your passion is photography you cannot go to UK and not visit St James Park. It is so tranquil and beautiful! The animals in the park are lovely, and very tame. Thus, I would also recommend this park for families with small children.
Great to get away from London business. So big SJP never feels overcrowded. Great lake and duck area. Nice to go through before hitting Buck Palace.

One of London's best parks. We're known for our parks in London, and this is one of the best. Great location, lovely statues, very well kept. Check it out if you're in the area. And read 'a ramble in St James Park' if you want a glimpse of the less than finer side of the park's history.

Winter gloom, happy squirrels. This park would be lovely after winter when the leaves start to bud, but was a bit gloomy and muddy this time. It did feel like a tranquil place in the middle of a busy city, and I saw some very happy squirrels.

The best park. In a city of great parks, Saint James's stands out because of the richness of its water fowl population. Worth the trip to see the pelicans, sometimes not so cool, as when they manage to catch and swallow a pigeon...but otherwise pretty neat!!!

A nice pass by but not a destination. This is beautiful to see. Hyde Park and Kensington Gardens are both a little more interesting. If you are in this area, be sure to stop by Picadilly Circus (a nice Time Square like area) and also Buckingham Palace all within walking distance.

Lovely afternoon. After a long walk in London streets this is the place to relax and enjoy the fresh air.
If you are lucky and it is a sunny day it is one of best places to read ,picnic and enjoy the weather . Also it is in a great location.

A perfect oasis in the heart of London. I run around St James's Park almost every day throughout the year and it is a constantly changing haven for wildlife in the heart of the city. Flanked by Buckingham Palace at one end and Horseguards at the other you can be watching the pelicans one minute and then see the changing of the guard with all is unique pomp and ceremony the next. Just around the corner are the Houses of Parliament, Big Ben and Westminster Abbey, so its the perfect place to stop for a breath of fresh air on a trip to see the very best London has to offer.

a bit of peace in busy city. Went for a small walk after long day sightseeing. Grabbed a cup of coffee and sandwich nearby.Well kept ponds with ducks and even pelicans! Don't forget to bring nuts for squirrels!

Don't miss the Pelicans and Herons. We were walking by a park entrance and what should I see in the duck lake section but 2 Pelicans and a gray heron landed. the Pelicans were introduced in the 1600's a gift from Russian....a pleasant surprise.

Pretty in Winter too. Those from the US might be used to everything going dormant and brown in the winter. But London is still a lovely shade of green. While I could infer how much prettier the park would be in other seasons, it was lovely in Mid-December as well.
Nice afternoon. This park is quaint and nice. We had a lovely afternoon just laying about and reading books after a long two weeks of travel!

Nice to get away for a walk through the park. Nice to walk around here - especially if the weather is nice - to get away from the crowds. Park is nicely set-up - good place for a pick-nick in the park (good weather days)

Lovely park in the summer. We've been going to and taking ppl to St Jame's for many years. It's a lovely spot for a picnic on a rare London summer's day! Plenty of views, squirrels, birds and other wildlife to keep everyone entertained and it's so close to all the major touristy spots. Even in the winter months, it's still lovely to wander around.
Take your time and enjoy the walk. Beautiful park, with friendly squirrels, plenty of flowers, trees a nice bridge. A peaceful quiet park. Enjoy the fresh air.
Right by Buckingham Palace. Beautiful ponds and gardens. Geese and squirrels will come right up to the small fences along the paths to be fed right out of your hands.
Loads of Wildlife. Lovely part of London with a lake and loads of wildlife. Plenty of Squirrels and birds. Right near Horse Guards Parade too.

Classic England. We had a beautiful afternoon walk through the park and it was raining the entire time. We would have loved to go back on a sunny day but ran out of time. It will be on the short list for our next visit
Squirrels!. IT is full of squirrels: remember to take some nuts with you: if you have kids (and live in a place where squirrels are rare to see) , they will never forget breading them

Pelicans. I have always wanted to see Pelicans and hate zoo's and I was told that they had pelicans in St James park, they were wonderful as were the other birds and wildlife, lots of other people where enjoying the sunshine gardens and wildlife as well.
tourist hell .... lovely when out of season to walk round but pointless when in season as tourists make it impossible !
Beautiful. Beautiful manicured gardens full of squirrels and gorgeous flowers. It's a lovely place to wander through, or rent a barclays bike! Great to walk through on a day out in London.
nice stroll. always loved this park since I was a child. Nice to wander quietly and then go and see the pelicans. Lots of squirrels too that are friendly!
Nice walk. A lot off animals coming to your hands especially if you have something to eat,nice place to walk and have a coffe in

A lovely escape in the lap of nature, amidst the hustle and bustle of London. St James Park is an absolutely lovely place in the heart of London. I visited the place In May 2012 and was mesmerized by the sheer beauty of the place. Acres and acres of colorful flowers, ponds, pigeons and many other birds, You would feel so peaceful and relaxed at the place. A perfect way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon.
New Years Day 2013. Great morning walking around the park. If you like feeding squirrels by hand take a bag of nuts, it'll keep you entertained for hours.
On a sunny Sunday morning - how nice?. We walked and walked in this beautiful park on a lovely rare sunny Sunday morning - a little piece of heaven in London
walk through me and see the Queen. nice historic park that gives the vibe of " I am royal". on the other end around the corner is The Palace
Great stroll. this park is a great little green space inbetween the busy roads around westminster. You can get some beautiful photo's of buckingham palace from certain points.
pidgey pidgey pidgey. Kid loved the birds and squirrels. Had a Restroom. You could tell people fed the animals bc they are not shy. Not even the large swan.
My favourite park in London. From all the central London's parks or gardens I've seen, I most enjoy St James's. Not the biggest or the most famous, but the most pleasant one.

Small but lovely. Being situated so close to Westminster and Buckingham, I would recommend St. James Park as a sort of mid-way respite between hopping from attraction to attraction. The beauty of the park is particularly accentuated during good, sunny weather, and the presence of the ducks and the birds make for cute company. Its a fantastic place to take a short walk through if you want to get to Buckingham Palace via a scenic route, which will recharge you and get you ready for yet another iconic London landmark on your itinerary.
Lovely night time walk from the Stafford Hotel. Loved the views of magnificent houses along the walk from the passage way in front of The Stafford Hotel towards Buckingham Palace.
Lovely park. I could watch the birds and squirrels all day. Not a huge park but lovely paths and bridges and we stopped at a nice cafe for a tasty coffee and cake.

Best royal park in London. I love this park. It has all the things you want in. Royal park - a lake, lots of birds inc swans, romantic bridges, amazing views of all the royal and famous buildings and smack bang in the middle of London

Green and pleasant. One of our great parks - and overlooking Buckingham Palace is an added bonus. Lovely views down to the London Eye too. A green and pleasant place to wander and spend some quiet time.

A wonderful stop and stroll!. Our 1st day in London, we traveled thru St. James Park on our way to Buckingham Palace. Simply beautiful! We went back days later to enjoy a take away lunch in the beautiful surroundings. An Oasis in the city!

Beautiful Park. This beautiful park is well-kept and situated in the heart of London's top attractions. A must stroll through is required. A picnic on sunnier days is a joy and visiting will always be a pleasure no matter the time of year.
squirrels galore. love walking through this park, lakes iced over and plenty of squirrels...so cute. plenty of characters too. only then a short walk to Buckingham Palace.

fun!. me and my boyfriend simply walked through it to get to buckingham palace and it was so much fun! the squirrels climbed on us, and the ducks came over. there was a lot of different wild life, and everything seemed so friendly. the lake was also very pretty!

A romantic place for a summer picnic. Grab some snacks from one of the local supermarkets and wander down to find yourself a small corner of grass. Yes it gets busy but its still a lovely place for an hour away from the bustle of London. The coffee from the park outlets is surprisingly nice!

Delightful in the centre of London. This beautiful little an oasis of peace in the very centre of town. Lovely lake, beautiful trees and flower beds. In the summer a splendid place to picnic. If you are in town shopping or whatever and you want some peace and quiet or just to relax and kill a couple of hours St James is ideal.
St. James. Probably my favourite park out of all the parks in London. I love spending a couple of hours just walking in the park. There are always people around but it is never crowded.
Fascinating waterfowl. A stroll through St. James Park is enhanced by the exotic waterfowl in its lake. The park's paths provide a delightful alternative to walking on Pall Mall.
Think this is the Theatre and Brasserie?. Great staff, good food and brilliant version of Daddy Long Legs playing there. Thoroughly wonderful evening.
Delightful. Something interesting to look at each way you turn, and the birdlife is abundant. There are good facilities here, toilets, food etc. A lovey way to spend a few hours, or even a whole day!
Way to Buckingham. We strolled thru this park on our way to the Buckingham Palace. On the other side of the park is Horse Guards parade. A nice park connecting indeed!

Absolutely Beautiful Park. St James's Park is absolutely beautiful and a pleasure to walk through. It is very well maintained and there is so much lovely wildlife to watch as you stroll.The squirrels are very friendly and they will come right up to you to take nuts out of your hands! Great fun!If only there were parks as lovely as this all over the place.
Daisy the dowager of outlook parks here.. Beautiful park in a great location, remember do not feed the geese it ruins dinner. A country oasis in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the big city.

A lovely park but, oh, the crowds!. The park is beautifully landscaped. There are plenty of pleasant walks. And it couldn't be more central, situated as it is between Trafalgar Square. There is also an excellent cafe and restaurant with outside seating. But convenience can be a curse. At weekends, you can hardly move because of the sheer number of people taking a stroll or trying to jog along the main pathways. Try to go there early or late in the day, or during the week, or take a walk away from the main pathways, if you want something resembling peace and (relative) quiet.
Anyone for Goose??. Adults and kids alike will love the wildlife this park has to offer.The geese looked fat and tasty...although I would never eat one.

Love this park!. I love St Jame's Park. You can feed the ducks and on a nice day just sit and relax and watch the world go by. It's nice to get away from the huste and bustle of the city. So when you're feet are fed up of walking around the city just get to St Jame's for a sit down and don't forget to take some bread with you for the ducks.

Nice park...but 3 pound for a deck chair?. Very nice picturesque park with lots of squirells and birds. Nice atmosphere hete. A bit shocked when I sat on a deck chair with my newspaper and then a foreign man charged me 3 pound to do so...I thought they were hete to sit on at your own leisure...oh well, thats life. Nice place for a stroll though and only a couple of minutes walk to the palace.
Squirrel Central. The park was lovely getting back to normal from after the games but the best part was the appearance of squirrels all over the place

Favourite park in London.. I travel to London a lot and I always make sure that I have time to visit St James Park as it can be the perfect escape from all of all the hustle and bustle of shopping crowds. It's also a great place for brunch/lunch as the "Inn the Park" cafe serves really quality food. Strongly recommend as it is a must see at any time of the year.

Our Sunday morning haven.. Always in London first week in December.We alway's walk through St James park after breakfast on Sunday, and always take nut's for the squirrels, they take them from your hands.It is a very pleasant walk and so much better than Hyde park.Horseguards parade on one side and Buckingham palace on the other.Then back to the shops !!
My FAVOURITE park. Winter summer autumn or spring, there is always something to see. Gorgeous trees, plants and bird life. Vies of bucking ham palace and the eye. Don't miss this visit

Excellent place to visit for New Years Eve Celebrations. Excellent place to visit for New Years Eve Celebrations, plenty of bars and pubs near by and a great view of the fantastic firework displays that are on in London to mark the occassion.
One of the best. Take some nuts so you can hand feed the friendly squirrels if this is your thing. A must-see romantic view in all directions from the bridge.
lovely park and restaurant. Pretty and central park. Part of the reason for our visit was to eat at "In the Park" cafe. Very warm service and lovely traditional English food

Lovely Experience.. We were there during the Paralympics but the gardens had obviously been spruced up prior to all the Olympics. There was a real buzz all through London and evryone was happy and friendly. The birds on the lake are also beautiful.
st james park. what a excellent park the toilets were very clean and the coffee bar around the park are excellent loads of ducks squirrels perfect place to relax

Impressive large and beautiful garden, lot of place to sit down, and relax. The squirrels and other animals that run there freely, has a great impact on the relaxation a person can get during the day (and even nights). Near the royal palace, you can sit down, relax, hear the birds and watch the animals going around you looking for food and entertainment.Passing by, can get you all the batteries charged for the next task you are planning next.
green oasis in the middle of london. right in the middle of all the sights, yet an oasis of peace and quiet if you want to pause and relax
Not bad but worth the walk. Nice park with the obvious nice view but best in the summer or on a sunny day. Simply a park with a lake.

Changing of the Guards. I went to the changing of the guards in December and was naive enough to think that there wouldn't be that big of a crowd. I came half an hour early (11:00) and the square in front of Buckingham palace was already packed. If you want a good spot to see the entire procession I would reccomend going even earlier (maybe 1hr or 1.5 hrs). I can't even imagine how full it must be in the summer time.

Pretty place. Even in winter still pretty. I was lucky to see it on a sunny day with prettu dappled winter sunshine through the trees. A wealth of water birds to be seen and very tame squirrels which may even climb the odd person. Good views towards Westminster including the abbey and Parliament.
a walk on the wild side. walking through St James Park was a real joy there were a lot of people about lots and lots of ducks,geese and squirrels jumping around a very enjoyable walk

Nice park in central London. I'm a Londoner and I can say that this park is just great in the heart of London. Located between Buckingham palace and Trafalgar Square, you can have a picnic there in summer or sunbath or even enjoy a long walk when it's not warm.

A stroll in the park. We had gone to see the changing of the guard at the palace and decided on a walk in the park. What a lovely place. We loved all the different kinds of wild life there and my daughter loved how the squirrels came when you called them.

A quiet oasis in central London. A quiet park to stroll in anytime but also a very convenient route from Victoria/St James to Picadilly. Perfect combination of lakes trees and vistas which are attractive in all seasons. Convenient picnic area for lunch if you are a visitor to local attractions.
A sunday walk in St. James´s Park. The weather was cold but sunny on that Sunday. Walking trough the park is relaxing and enjoyable. Take that short walk and relax in a amazing city.
Take time for a stroll through this beautiful park. Swans, geese, lots of other birds, squirrels, beautiful scenery and views. You simply must make sure you take the time to stroll through this park.

Beautiful park to visit when in London. If you are within the Buckingham palace area, this park is the place to go. I love walking through the park and most especially, the perfect setting to have the autumn foliage photos. Highly recommend for a short stroll and picnic with your friends and significant other.
peaceful, green, well kept grounds. A pleasant walk, lots of friendly squirrels. Nice and clean, a breath of fresh air between the hotel and the sites and shops

Pleasant park in the middle of the city. Lovely park to rest when you are doing rounds of visiting places in London by Buckingham palace, The Mall. It is nice to take a break to have sandwiches and carry on your day.

If you only have time to visit one park in London - this is it!. If you only have time to visit one park in London, St James's Park is it. It's a mini size of Hyde Park and it's the most beautiful of all. Please budget 30 minutes to walk through the park (if you are in a rush or in fast pace)...or 90 minutes if you take your time to enjoy the place and walk.

Wonderfull!. When I go to London with friends who have never been before we usually watch the changing of the guard. An important part of this for me is getting there by walking through St James's Park. The plants, the wildlife, (especially the squirrels playing under the trees) is just so beautiful at any time of the year!

Always a great place to visit. A lovely walk around massive gardens, loads of wildlife local and imported. Photo opportunities a plenty. Great to see the large diverse range of nationalities, make sure you take some peanuts for the squirrels and not to forget some bread for the ducks. What was great to observe were the well behaved and polite children from France Spain and even Germans, then the UK children with no manners and fould language. We could learn a lot from our european neighbours on family matters... Rant over
More the wifes cup of tea. The wife made me stroll along but i wasnt too much up for it . Would recommend more in Summer and if you have kids or dogs. Good for runners and cyclist

Yes, it's just a park, but a good one.. Every time we're in London, we always take a day to stroll down to St. James Park. Makes a nice break from the flurry of trying to do and see everything that London has to offer, and lets us level out. The considerable variety of birds, ducks, swans and storks, the green grass, the benches for people watching - perfect! And, of course there is the prerequisite hot dogs on offer.Love it!!

An autumn stroll in St. James's Park. Currently there is a lot of work underway to restore the beauty of the park after the grass at the Westminster end suffered badly from the Paralympics. That aside it is a beautiful park and is too good to miss if visiting Buckingham Palace

Beautiful and clean park. We had a great time at the park. It was very peaceful and nice weather. We were there during summer. The days were longer and so we do really enjoyed the beautiful scenery around it.

Nice break. My husband and I enjoyed taking a "break" from the typical sightseeing to stroll through this park. I would suggest finding one of the many lounge chairs and people watching. A lovely way to walk to Buckingham Palace.
Autumn stroll. This was lovely walk on a sunny autumn/winter morning with squirrels bounding in all directions and we were lucky enough to see the changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace.
wonderful place. One of the mosr beautiful parks i haev ever seen in my life. if you are in London - a must-see place. flowers, peaceful alleys, it was trully the hightloght of our trip. and free!

Loved the birds!. A lovely park for a stroll or picnic right next to Buckingham palace. We went in the fall and the trees were pretty with colored leaves. We saw several varieties of geese, ducks, herons, a pelican and other animals. No entrance fee. Worth seeing!

peace in the midst of chaos. With Buckingham Palace at one end and the government's bunker at the other, St. James Park represents some sanity in an insane world. There is an amazing view of the roof tops of St. James and Whitehall - the lake is a picture with its wild life floating by. Sitting on a bench you have to wonder who planted the trees and when. Even when it is full of deck chairs on a hot summer's day, this little park maintains its sense of space. Love it!

A wonderful green space in the middle of it all. Take a moment to rest the legs and enjoy the scenery and wildlife in this outstanding park. All manner of birds to see, squirrels running about. Very relaxing.

Saintly St. Jame's. Very relaxing walking through the park, a huge variety of birds giving entertainment to passers-by, squirrels cheekily asking for food. Lovely views whichever way you look. The pleasant sounds of military bands in the background. A serene retreat in the centre of London

Take a stroll, bring a picnic. We loved walking in St Jame's Park. A great respite in the middle of it all. Take a sandwich and find a bench and just relax, especially if the sun is out. Giant white Pelicans with whom you can pose. Usually pretty busy, but lovely.
Loved the wildlife. Funny little squirrels and even a pelican in the middle of London! Beautiful park for walking and relaxing.

Excellent for a walk. Nice ambiance, relaxing and very walkable with squirrels running around you and sometimes coming towards you so that you can hand feed them. A must if you visit London along with Hyde Park - of course - and Green Park

coffee at peyton and byrne cafe... Despite closing up well before closing time.. they reopened the cake sales... soya milk available, free wi fi, great position in park with lovely view, stylish and clean, friendly staff :-)

Oasis In The Ciity. Beautiful park just steps from Buckinham Palace and Parlimment. You are transported from the hustle and bustle of downtown London into a quiet oasis. It also connects to both Hyde Park, and Kensington Gardens for an even longer walk

Autumn beauty. Loved this park in autumn. Superb view on Buckingham palace away from the tourists. Also a great way to walk from Buckingham palace to Trafalgar square and the theater district. Fortnum and Mason's in the neighbourhood.

A small haven backing on to busy London. This tiny Park is a real gem, nestled between Buckingham Palace, The Palace of Westminster, the former Palace of St James, Trafalgar Square, Green Park, Whitehall, it is wonderful to visit early in the morning, when the sun comes up, in Spring, before the tourists discover it!

Oasis. Despite the number of tourist this can be a nice calm place to visit. If you are lucky you may find yourself sitting with a Pelican.
Great views from the bridge in the middle- particularly through to Buckingham Palace. Take your camera.

Best park in London. Great park clean
always goes there everytime i'm visiting london worth a visit
Really like spending looking at all different type of flowers

Wonderful Stroll. St. James Park is amazing to get 'lost' in. We had a great day to start with, nice and sunny and warm. So much wildlife to watch as they go about their day. The gardens are taken well care. A worthwhile experience for serenity and beautiful views.

Fantastic picture of old London. St James was an elite quater of georgian England. this can still be seen in the area both east and west of the park. The west is the site of the former Carlton House - the monarch's palace prior to Buckingham Palace. As such the park has been in the areas of the royals for hundreds of years and it shows.
Simply delightful. A trip to St. James's Park is just lovely. It's so pretty and serene. The cafe in the middle of the park is really nice too, well worth a visit.

London's most beautiful park in spring. Especially great when spriong flowers blooming! And great to watch animals such as pelicans and squirrels! I love London's parks but this one clearly is my favourite! Make sure you have a look at the little cottage bu the lake - very pittoresque!

Lazy mid morning stroll in St. James' Park. Don't feed the pelicans! Sat with coffee outside cafe in the park and watched the bird life and squirrels chase after every scrap of bread and nuts they were offered. Had just gone to the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace and strolled through the park heading for the National Gallery in Trafalgar Square. Lovely falling leaf colour. Could easily sit there and while away an hour.
Lovely. Beautiful, scenic.. Wish the weather had been better! Loved the birds... Definitely a well worth trip if you enjoy walking!

Wonderful park! Nature on the city. I went to London for sports events, I never meant to go for parks. Back in Brazil, I dont care about parks. But this one is very beautiful, with the lake and the squirrels who come so close to you! And here you can lay on the grass: awesome!

quiet oasis. one of my favourite places in London
love to relax here in the afternoon after a busy day
make sure you check out the pelicans and other birds in the lake
Clean and tidy. This is lovely park, huge but lovely, was nice and clean when we visited with council people to be seen cleaning up and tending things, also busy as usual

Ala Royale English style. Well, if u are into everything English then this is a great location for you. The park is a stone throw's away from the popular Buckingham Palace so, try your luck in catching a member of the British monarchy passing by the park.Ideal for strollers, feeding ducks & swans, sharing ice-cream, cycling for health & nature watch as it is teeming with cute squirrels, birds & butterflies.Great for kids too with carousels & small playground.

One of my favorite parks in central London. It looks particularly beautiful in the fall. Located near Buckingham Palace, it has a gorgeous lake and a resident Pelican who loves people and basks in attention. It will pose for photos and seem to enjoy it - I've never seen such a prima Donna bird. Quite endearing.

Pleasant surprise. I cut through the park on a walk to a business meeting. As a boy, i spent a lot of time at my grandmothers house. She had a large sycamore tree at the end of her driveway. i spent days under that tree, therefore the first thing i noticed in this park was the giant sycamore trees... their leaves were beginning to turn and fall. i snapped two pictures (attached) from a bridge with my iPad (i travel on business and don't carry an extra camera). to my surprise, one of the pictures shows Buckingham Palace quite well. I hope to get back on day and spend some time...
Lots of Squirrels. My children loved the park - we went squirrel hunting - there were lots and very friendly. Plenty of wildlife to look out for.

Strolling through Jolly Olde England. Having read so many books where this Park was a backdrop made this park truly enjoyable. It really is a nice spot to go for a walk and people watch. It is well tended and is a nice break from the hustle of the business side of London.

Squirrels everywhere. Saw a pelican eating a pigeon!. If you want to relax or stroll through a park in central London, and you like the idea of squirrels jumping on your legs (if they think you have food), St. James's is the place to be. In fact, the quickest way to get from Big Ben and parliament to Buckingham palace, is to walk through it. Best on a spring or summers' day.
Walking is a pleasure. The Park has a very large extension, so try to walk as much as you can, because it is a pleasure. Read the history involved before talking the walking tour.

The Heart of London. What's not to like about St. Jame's Park? It's all about location, location, location in the heart of London. And also tradition and beauty. Every visitor can easily stroll from Buckingham Palace to Big Ben or to Trafalgar Square in just minutes. Or stroll the opposite direction through the connecting Green Park and onward to the connecting Hyde Park. What a wonderful park system and way to enjoy the natural beauty of London :-)
A lovely stroll. Walked through Hyde Park and then St James' park. Both lovely and relaxing to walk through. A bit of an oasis in the centre of London.

A favourite spot in London. Very close to some of the main attractions of the city and still, one of the nicest, greenest, loveliest places there.Never miss a chance to go there - and bring some nuts with you: squirrels will love you forever...

Strolling in the park. The weather at the weekend was not good for a slow walk but all the same from Horseguards parade to Buckingham Palace it is a very nice walk. It route is well signed and it brings you strraight out at the roudabout at Buckingham Palace. On hot days you can sit and have an ice cream this weekend however it was coffees all round to keep warm however still pleasureable

One of London's lungs. Always a pleasant stroll from St James's Park tube to my clubs on Pall Mall. Yes, it is that sort of park, in the moddle of things. The human factor is fascinating, with all manner of interactions and human dramas taking place. Considering its massive footprint, the place is in pretty good shape and it offers great views of the heart of London. Good loos as well. Recommended for fixing your bearings and getting a feel for the West End.

Nice little walk, not too fancy. It probably is an angle of the British value, very simple and direct.Very much unlike the bustling, sometimes, sassy, London, it provides a certain humbleness and certainly it made me reflect on my stay in those days.
Lovely. Particularly in the summer, a large park, great to relax when on a long walk in our wonderful metropolis.
Beautiful in Spring. The park is lovely in Spring, do try out the restaurant in the middle of the park. Premium prices for food but the view is fantastic for an afternoon hangout.
Relaxing. Love this place just to wander about. It takes me out of the push and shove of London. Could spent lots of time her jus people watching.

Wonderful autumn colours in St James's Park. We visited London last Monday and as it was a beautiful sunny day walked from Victoria through the park to Covent Garden. We were lucky enough to catch the changing of the guards which started just as we got there. The park is probably at its best in autumn with the beautiful trees with the changing colours. The number of different species of wildfowl never ceases to amaze in the middle of London and as always the squirrels are a delight, not a touch of fear. There were a lot of tourists taking photos and generally enjoying the peace and quiet. We walked back through after lunch and it was just a beautiful in the fading sunlight. A wonderful time.

Pretty, pretty, pretty. Central London has 5 astonishing parks, each lovely in their own distinct way. St. Jame's is one of my favorites. When you tire of the crowds of Westminster be sure to stroll through for some natural beauty and tranquility.

Always a joy to be in St. James's Park. London is a town for walking, and what better or more beautiful place than within St. James's Park----always see alot of dogs there, some runners and once in a while I have seen people on horseback, which is a thrill. When the colors change, even more gorgeous. I never tire of looking at this great park.

Beautiful. It's a great place to spend the last day of your visit in a relaxing atmosphere outdoors, surrounded by an amazing variety of trees and different animals species, a wonderful lake and the peace and serenity that you are looking for a day in a busy and thigh schedule trip!

most beautiful park in Central London. The swans and the lake make this just an ideal place to come visit before going shopping or dining in the West End. Picturesque and peaceful you feel as if you are somewhere else

St. James' Park, a green oasis in central London. It is said that in wartime London Churchill would leave his underground war office and take a stroll in St. James' Park when the all clear signal was sounded. He used to observe the ducks in the ponds of the park, and take great delight in their timeless insouciance even when the city was under siege. The calming rhythms of nature continue to charm and delight the visitor to St. James' Park, where benches are available without charge, and the great urban space is humanized by people on bicycles, animals on leish, nannies pushing baby carriages and office workers enjoying a sandwich.

october break. lovely place to walk or relax in the centre of all the attractions of the city on your way from west minster to the mall and onto buckinham palace, with lots of colourful plants and shrubs as well as wildlife both in the trees and on the lake , you can feed the ducks, swans or the very friendly pidgeons or squirrells
squirrels everywhere. absolutly brilliant nice stroll round taking pictures watching the squirrels go upto people for food walked a full circle round lovely walk well worth it if you have the energy
Serene park. Beautiful place with lots of different ducks and very friendly squirrels! Just a stones throw away from Buckingham Palace

Beautiful in the spring. As we all know, the weather is rather unpredictable in the UK, so try to pick a sunny day to see the delights of St James' Park. Many other attractions are within a short walk - Buckingham Palace, the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey & so forth.

NIce park. Tranquil park with nice water features in central London. Beside Buckingham Palace.
Well worth a visit.

Spies and pelicans. I love St James's Park, it's one of the great London parks and in the summer, where better to stroll or sit enjoying the bandstand music?It can seem a bit dreary in the winter but wrap up warmly, enjoy the views of Buckingham Palace, Horse Guards Parade or the Mall and walk briskly from St James's Park up into Green Park (next to Buck Palace) and then up towards Hyde Park - and if you're in walking mode you can even head onwards to Holland Park.It's a great walk, you see some of the loveliest parts of London and you're making the most of London's essential and pretty green lung!And if you're in the mood for something a bit different for lunch - head towards Piccadilly Road, running along the edge of Green Park, turn left and end up in Shepherd Market.And re St James's Park, enjoy the walks around the lake, enjoy the views and the pelicans and remember - those civil servants with their briefcases could be latter-day George Smiley's swapping secrets!

Wonderful views of Buckingham Palace. A peaceful haven in the middle of the city the autumn colours were wonderful Had a great sight with the Royal Household cavalry practicing for Remberance day very spectacular

Shut the door, Palmer!. and take a walk ... over the footbridge where Ross and Dalby skirmished with umbrellas and traded enigmatic glances with only the geese and coote to eavesdrop, Buck House's standard signalling all is well, the glint of the Victoria Memorial through the willow, Scott's Foreign Office belvedere aloft, the roar of traffic reduced to a gentle hum, gravel underfoot then grass and space to stretch, unwrap a sandwich, open the flask, even have a nap, head supported on a briefcase or rolled umbrella ...

My favourite park. I am biased. I love St. James’s Park.The oldest of the London parks, it is bordered by the Mall, Horse Guards Parade, Birdcage Walk and Buckingham Palace, all of which were extensively filmed during the Olympics. It is steeped in tradition and history: coronations, weddings, funerals, parades of all kinds, street theatre, daily glimpses of the Guards or Household Cavalry on ceremonial duty, all these have taken place around it. Statues and memorials abound. Equally iconic are Duck Island Cottage with its vegetable garden; the Blue Bridge across the lake, which has featured in so many films, including 101 Dalmatians; and the summer Bandstand. But it is the passing of the seasons in the peaceful, immaculately kept gardens that brings me back whenever I can. At the moment though, parts of the park are still recovering after the removal of all the temporary Olympic structures The pelicans are great favourites. There have been pelicans in the park since the Russian ambassador presented a pair to King Charles II in 1664. However, they were banned for a short interlude for eating the pigeons! You should not feed them, they are given plenty of fish every day. And take care if you come across one wandering around, they won’t hurt you but can become frightened if surrounded.If you take the time, you will see a large variety of birds and animals, including tame squirrels and wild foxes, living or passing through the park. Feeding the birds is a favourite pastime for many. White bread is discouraged but according to one of the Park keepers you can “Feed swans lettuce - they really like it.”
Historic. The grounds were so well maintained. Wasnt sure if this was due to the proximity to the 2012 Olympics or if its always so well maintained!

My favourite park. This park is my favourite in central London - small and compact - lake in middle - lots of birds - squirrels - deckchairs - band concerts (in the summer) - cafe - icecream - fairytale house on a little island - B Palace at one end, Horseguards at the other, and the Mall - love it, love it, love it :)

Great to get away from the traffic. A great way to either just cut across a bit of London, as well as the great gardens, the lake and all that. Even though you will never get away from the noise of the cars, you at least do not have to look at them for a while!

Lovely Park. I love St James's Park which is very handy if you are staying at Rubens Hotel. The park is full of wildlife and I love watching the squirrels dashing up trees and eating! The floral displays are lovely and when leaving the park you can walk through to Horse Guards Parade and onto Downing Street and Big Ben. There is a cafe too. I always visit here when in London. There is also a snack bar where you can get lovely ice creams and tea/coffee to eat outside. There is nothing to dislike about this park. It's opposite Buckingham Palace which is great.

A pretty and historic retreat in the centre of London. This pretty park is just big enough to stretch the legs or, more likely, to sit and relax away from the bustle of central London. The lake is well-used by friendly ducks and other avian visitors and it is possible to select sitting places where all the surrounding buildings are obscured by trees. A favourite rus in urbe.

Bring bread to feed the ducks. Children liked this park because there were a lot of ducks, geese and squirrels eager to have a snack. It is a pleasant walk from the Churchill War Room to Buckingham Palace.

My favorite Central London park!. I went to St. James's Park for the first time before visiting Buckingham Palace and I absolutely adored it! As soon as I got past the fence I was entranced by the greenery and how lush all the trees looked. It was a perfect day as well: chilly around 60F but very sunny, so the light was amazing. There were plenty of people and wildlife about as well, so there was a lively atmosphere. As recommended by others, the footbridge was a great spot to see both the Palace and the buildings by the Thames, all surrounded by gorgeous trees. Being a Downton Abbey fan, I remembered seeing two of the characters walking down a lakeside path in this park, and I ended up finding that very spot during my visit. Despite the cold, it was a very lovely diversion in the middle of my mad schedule, and I found it just as beautiful (if not more so) than the other two Royal Parks surrounding Buckingham Palace.
A Park. it's just a park but it's very cool especially in a city like London. enjoy the quiet and openess while still being able to see the Palace and have the feel of London.

Beautiful park!. We walked through this park around 8am on a Sunday morning. It was mostly occupied by a few people jogging or walking their dogs, and a lot of birds and squirrels. Beautiful views of Buckingham Palace on one side of the lake, and London on the other.

Great views. I have often walked thro St James pk & it is full of great views of Buckingham palace & Horse guards & London eye. It also abundant Birds , squirrels , ducked & other wild life.
